news weird-news bride-shares-strict-list-wedding-"Bride-to-be shares her list of rules ahead of weddingByZahna EklundAudience writer:,  Feb |comments Thereaposs a seemingly endless list of traditions you can follow when it comes to your wedding day - whether thataposs the father of the bride walking her down the aisle, wearing a white wedding dress, or not allowing the bride and groom to see each other on the night before their big day. But one woman on TikTok has one tradition sheaposs definitely not going to be following when she ties the knot later this year, as itaposs made it onto her strict list of rules for her wedding day.And which tradition is the bride-to-be banning  The garter toss.Jasmine Cruz, who posts under the username @cruzjasmine, has insisted her husband wonapost be sticking his hands underneath her wedding dress to remove her garter in front of her family and friends - because she finds the tradition gross and weird. In a video explaining her list of rules, she said: Weaposre not doing the garter thing, thataposs gross. I already have to kiss a man in public in front of all these people. Now you want him to go under my dress and pretend to..., before making gagging noises and cutting herself off. Jasmineaposs other rules included making sure no one wears white except for the bride - which seemed to be so important to the woman that she accidentally listed it twice. And the bride-to-be is also banning kids from her wedding, except in instances where people are travelling from places that are too far away and need to bring their children with them, and her siblings who are all under .  She is also refusing entry to anyone that wasnapost invited and has set limits on how many plus ones sheaposs giving out to her guests. But not all of Jasmineaposs rules were strict, as she said sheaposs allowing her bridesmaids to wear whatever they want and is happy for them to throw on a dress or a suit - just as long as the colour scheme flows throughout all the members of the bridal party. The bride also jokingly listed bridesmaids are all [rainbow emoji] as a rule, but claried she didnapost mean for it to come across as a requirement, and instead meant that it just so happens that the bridal party are all members of the LGBTQ+ community. She said: It just kind of coincidentally worked out that all of my bridesmaids are all at least a little bit part of the LGBT community, and I love that. We just all are somehow a little bit ... yaposknow. I love that.  Jasmine and her fiance are paying for an open bar for their guests so expect them to take advantage of it, and have even said the vendors should be treated as guests when on their breaks. And Jasmineaposs final rule is one we probably all have listed for our weddings - no big announcements. She said: If youaposre pregnant, keep it to yourself. If you want to propose, keep that to yourself. Do not come to my wedding day and take the attention away from me and my man, you will be tackled. The list of rules has split opinion among the  million people who have viewed Jasmineaposs video, as some say her demands are just too strict. One person said: Wow she’s really strict. Just elope, that might be better for you to save you the headache of a wedding. While another added: Why do people not want people at their wedding  The more the merrier, why not  Why do you have to be so damn stingy and rude  But a third disagreed, insisting: I love the no garter rule, itaposs a really disturbing thing to do in front of family. And someone  wrote: As a former event planner, I approve all these. Weddings made me want to elope or do a small brunch.What do you think  Let us know in the comments below.Read MoreRead MoreMost Read Dont MissFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterComment MORE ON MarriageWeddingsWedding dayTikTokViral" data-immediate"data-immediate" to FREE email alerts with news to brighten your daySubscribeInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: i chucked out vatican looking
story: I was chucked out of the Vatican for looking too sexy - I felt so disrespectedWhile visiting Rome late last month, an influencer headed to the Vatican to take some snaps. However, she claims staff ordered her to leave on account of her being too sexyJuju felt disrespected after she was asked to leave Image: Jam Press @jujuvieira_oficialByJulia BanimAudience WriterLaura Abernethy:,  Feb |commentsInfluencer Juju Vieirawas had been enjoying a day at the Vatican on January , as part of her trip to Rome. Little did she know that her choice of outfit would prove to be an issue. The model, who is originally from Brazil, has alleged that she was asked to leave the holy site after being informed that she wasnapost dressed properly. Having been unaware that her fitted dress and long boots were against the rules, Juju says she felt disrespected by the man whoaposd asked her to leave, explaining that sheaposd simply gone to the Holy City to take pictures like everyone . Juju recalled: A gentleman who worked there came close to me and said that the place was for prayers and that I was not dressed properly and invited me to leave, aposkickedapos me out of the Vatican. Get the news you want straight to your inbox.for a Mirror newsletter here. She explained that she was embarrassed because there were other people there who heard this, adding that she felt disrespected. Unfortunately for Juju, the Vatican does enforce a strict dress code for both male and female visitors and shoulders and knees do need to be covered at all times. According to the official website: “Women are not permitted to wear sleeveless tops, crop tops, or tight shirts. Shoulders should be covered, andwearing a skirt or dress, it must cover the knees. Women are also advised to bring along a shawl and a pair of leggings when visiting during the colder months along with a light jacket that can be rolled up into a pleasingly tiny bag. However, Juju hadnapost known about this code prior to her visit and had simply planned her outfit as she usually would had she been out exploring any new place. She added: “I didnapost even know there were rules. A person of common sense will not visit the Vatican in club clothes. I was stylish in my winter clothes, everything matched. I went in comfortable clothes that I would feel good in for long walks. Comfort was my only concern. Sharing the story of this “unpleasant situation” on Instagram, Juju received plenty of sympathy from her , followers, with one person remarking, “this is absurd my friend. Another replied with a series of shocked face emojis. However, others explained that it wasnapost unusual for those breaking the dress code to be asked to leave, with a third person writing: “Well,you go dressed with deep necklines, very tight clothes, thataposs normal. They didn’t let my niece in also with a miniskirt and belly out. Have you experienced something similar  Let us know in the comments oremail us at yourmirror@mirror Read MoreRead MoreMost Read Dont MissFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterComment MORE ON VaticanViralBody image" data-immediate"data-immediate" to FREE email alerts with news to brighten your daySubscribeInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: man finds giant spider car
story: Man finds giant spider in his car and decides to keep it there as a pet for entire yearAfter finding a six-inch spider on his dashboard, a man decided to keep it around as a pet, with the enormous eight-legged critter having now lived in his car for an entire yearChris decided to keep the spider in his car Image: Chris Taylor   CATERS NEWSByJulia BanimAudience WriterJulia BanimAudience WriterSarah Fittock:,  Feb |commentsUpon encountering a huge, hairy six-inch spider chilling on their car dashboard, the majority of people would understandably use their own two legs to get as far away as possible. However, after making such a discovery back in February , Australian man Chris Taylor did no such thing, instead choosing to take on aposSteveapos as a pet. The -year-old safety manager has now allowed Steve to live freely inside his car for a full year, during which time sheaposs doubled in size.Having now become quite attached to his eight-legged stowaway, Chris has no plans to show her the door anytime soon.  Get the news you want straight to your inbox.for a Mirror newsletter here. Chris said: “She just appeared one day about a year ago on the dashboard when I stopped at the lights. She was only about half the size she is now though, I’ve watched her grow. I did get her out of the car a few months ago but the next day she was back under the sun visor, so she likes it in my car for some reason. Thankfully, Chris isnapost generally too spooked about spiders. However, he will admit that he doesnapost appreciate it when she falls into my lap, a thought that will no doubt make arachnophobes everywhere shudder.Heaposs also not too keen when his driving buddy appears cm above my head on the headlining while driving at mph.  Chris recalled: “I had her fall on my lap one time and almost hit the Sydney Harbour tunnel wall.I named him Steve, because why not  I have seen been told, however, that he is she. When I have passengers in my car they are often startled or scream. Steve is great at keeping me more alert when I drive. Although Chris likes Steve, he wouldnapost say theyaposre the best of friends just yet. However, he admits that heaposs more than happy leaving her to live in his car. Not only for the company but because no one wants to grab a ride with him anymore, saving him heaps of cash. The accidental spider owner explained: I’ll let her stay, I’m saving money as no one wants a lt anymore. I like her but wouldn’t say we’re close friends. Yet!I would be a bit sadshe decided to leave. Driving is far more exciting with her in there. title: marks  spencer shoppers puzzled
story: Marks  Spencer shoppers puzzled by skirt ad that looks like woman is shopltingA stylish new MS skirt has flown off the shelves, but shoppers are a bit puzzled by the choice of ad photographs, which arguably make the model look like shes up to no goodThe models face is obscured, and she looks to be in a hurry Image: MSByJulia BanimAudience WriterRachel Pugh:,  Feb |commentsIn a new advert for a long and stylish skirt, iconic retailer Marks  Spencer confidently declares that a monochrome moment is one you’ll never regret. However, a number of shoppers feel like the model in the ad photographs looks like sheaposs been up to some dodgy dealings that she will indeed ultimately live to regret, no matter how fashionable her aposmonochrome momentapos may be, reports Manchester Evening News. In the pics in question, the modelaposs face is completely obscured behind her hair, and she can be seen taking an exaggerated stride forward asattempting to get away sharpish without being seen. The black and white stripes donapost exactly help matters. Get the news you want straight to your inbox.for a Mirror newsletter here. Underneath an ad shared to Facebook, one shopper admitted that they thought it was a Crimewatch post, while another remarked this ad looks more like someone escaping the scene of a crime rather than highlighting the merchandise. A third amused person wrote: I thought it was a dodgy person that was sneaking away from a crime scene! I suppose it is clever marketing because it got our attention. Fortunately, the slightly shty undertone to the ad has done nothing to dent the popularity of the striped pleated midaxi skirt, which has since sold out in all sizes apart from a regular . The £ skirt - which looks much less sinister onsite - is said to come in a swishy pleated silhouette, which falls to an elegant midaxiwith an elasticated waist allowing for all-day comfort. Presumably, the comfort factor here isnapost intended for quick and more relaxing getaways. Having racked up a glowing five-star rating from  happy customers, itaposs clear that shoppers would still recommend this skirt whether youaposre heading out to dinner or planning some sort of heist. The Mirror has reached out to MS for comment.Do you have an interesting fashion or shopping-related story to share  Let us know in the comments or email us atyourmirror@mirror  Most Read Dont MissFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterComment MORE ON ShopltingClothes LineAdvertisingMarks  SpencerViral" data-immediate"data-immediate" to FREE email alerts with news to brighten your daySubscribeInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. news weird-news mcdonalds-worker-shares-how-big-"McDonalds worker reveals how a Big Mac burger is madeByCourtney PochinSenior Audience Writer:,  Feb |comments Itaposs been an exciting week for McDonaldaposs fans as the company launched their new twist on the iconic Big Mac burger.Yes, the Chicken Big Mac became available to purchase across the UK on February  and the reviews are in.The Mirroraposs taste test concluded that the burger was aposmessyapos but definitely worth a try - and as such people canapost stop talking about Big Macs. Because of this, a McDonaldaposs employee from the US decided to share a look at how the classic beef version is made and posted a step-by-step video of the process on TikTok.The video went viral and has caused a stir with fans of the fast-food chain. Get the news you want straight to your inbox. for a Mirror newsletter here. Posting under the username @essentialmcdonalds, the employee begins the footage by explaining how the three buns have dferent names and all get toasted.The top of the bun is known as the aposcrownapos, the bottom is the aposheelapos and the middle part is known as the aposclubapos. They are toasted on both sides then put into the burger box, with crown on top, heel on bottom and club on top of crown. Next one shot of Big Mac sauce is added on each side.  The man goes on to sprinkle dehydrated onions on top of the Big Mac sauce, before adding lettuce on each and two pickles on top and one piece of cheese on the bottom. A burger patty is added to both sides, then comes the most challenging part. He explains: You have to lt the club up and put it on top of the heel, so youaposve basically assembled a sandwich. Then you close it and youaposre done. The clip has been viewed  million times on social media, with over two million people liking it. Thousands also took the time to comment, with one person saying: IDK why but Iaposm obsessed with learning this lol. Another wrote: Mine never looks like that. Normally itaposs thrown in the box and I have to recover it. Others were shocked to learn that the Big Mac only came with one slice of cheese and some really wanted extra pickles.Do you have a McDonaldaposs story to share  We want to hear all about it. title: mum gets cheeky ruler tattoo
story: Mum gets cheeky ruler tattoo to measure penis sizes before sex to daughters horrorFormer Page Three model -year-old Tracy Kiss, who has more than  tattoos has opened up about her latest body art, explaining why shes had the cheeky inking added to her bodyThe practical body art is inked right down her arm Image: Jam Press @tracykissdotcomByJulia BanimAudience WriterLaura Abernethy:,  Feb |commentsA mum has opened up about her decision to have a discreet ruler inked on her arm, allowing her to measure theof a partneraposs manhood. -year-old Tracy Kiss, from Buckinghamshire, opted for a series of visually attractive dots lined up from her elbow right up to her pinky finger, measuring every inch and a half of skin. All Tracy has to do is place her arm next to a partner to figure out his size, an attribute the yoga instructor and le coach says she really enjoys knowing about for imagination purposes when you’re not together. Given that the tat is rather discreet, this allows Tracy to innocently reach up to stroke his stomach whilst taking a glance at my arm alongside it to count the inches rather than guessing with hands.Get the news you want straight to your inbox.for a Mirror newsletter here. Tracy, who describes her ink as being a somewhat discreet but practical design and tool to enhance my le, explaining: I’m a woman who enjoys pleasure, body confidence and intimacy and feel that women have just as much right as men to speak honestly about sexual encounters. With a personal best of  rolls between the sheets in one day, Tracy has a high sex drive and knows exactly what sheaposs looking for in a prospective partner. The former Page Three girl added: Being single and online dating at present, there seems to be a massive energy around the height of guys as every girl daydreams of a ft+ Prince in shining armour to sweep her off of her feet, whereas in all honesty, I dream of a ”+ Prince instead! For Tracy, the devil is in the detail and she really does enjoy knowing the size of a partner, explaining: Whilst some people keep hold of underwear or sleep in their partneraposs t-shirts, I enjoy knowing all measurements for imagination purposes when you’re not together. Tracy began considering this cheeky design following an encounter with a date who didn’t know his size, or rather didn’t choose to reveal it to me. Shocked by this admission, Tracy found her partneraposs penis to be incredibly impressive and couldnapost believe he’d never taken the time to measure himself. She joked at the time that she would bring a ruler with me next time. Her date asked her where it was and they both enjoyed a good laugh about it. This conversation led Tracy to start thinking about getting a tattoo in inches that I could take with me everywhere thus satisfying her need to measure things discreetly without making anybody feel judged or insecure. She added: “It’s not all about size, it’s what you do with it and how your partner makes you feel when building an intimate connection, but for those who enjoy finer details it really is the cherry on the cake for me.” According to Tracy, her -year-old daughter Millisent is now at an age where she realises my cheeky sense of humour and picks up on adult jokes which she’d missed before. She added: She suspected my tattoo was purposely measured in inches and I may have confirmed her suspicions when measuring cucumbers. Going forward, Tracy is rather tempted to add some dots from my thumb to my index finger to measure girth at the same time, however, she is worried that this might make her intentions too obvious. She added: I guess it all depends on where somebody is looking when I whip it out to count!”Have you opted for an unusual tattoo  Let us know in the comments or email us at yourmirror@mirrorRead MoreRead MoreMost Read Dont MissFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterComment MORE ON Tattoos" data-immediate"data-immediate" to FREE email alerts with news to brighten your daySubscribeInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: mum mortified after x rated
story: Mum mortied as racy video for husband is accidentally shared with , Facebook palsA woman has been left red-faced after accidentally live-streaming an X-rated video meant for her husband instead of privately messaging it to him - and her son isnt impressed eitherShes mortied by her mistake ByCourtney PochinSenior Audience Writer:,  Mar Updated:,  Feb |comments A mum was left feeling absolutely mortied after making an epic Facebook blunder, The middle-aged woman from Bulgaria has told how she accidentally live-streamed a rather racy video of herself to her , Facebook friends, instead of privately messaging it.The saucy clip, which showed Zeinepa Galibova in bed, was intended for her husbandaposs eyes only.She claims her partner is currently away, working in the UK and she clearly misses him a great deal - so decided to spice things up. However, sheaposs definitely regretting the decision, as instead of sending the video to her long-distance lover, the woman accidentally uploaded it as a Facebook story, shocking her friends and family.  Get the news you want straight to your inbox.for a Mirror newsletter here. The x-rated clip was also viewed by the womanaposs -year-old son, who told local media in Tuhovishta, that he will be unable tohome for at least five years due to embarrassment. Galibovaaposs nearest and dearest have branded the video a sex-tape.As reported by The Sun the womanaposs husband was also very upset over the incident and refused to speak to his we for several days after.The woman claims the video was filmed out of boredom and she has had to turn to close friends to help her get over the social media mix-up. And sheaposs not the only one who has suffered an incredibly embarrassing moment like this - weaposve recently heard how a man came home to surprise his parents after being away in the military only to see them having sex. His parents got more of a shock than he had bargained for as he walked into their bedroom without knocking and caught them in the act. Joseph Pena had been away from his family in Colorado, USA, for the last two years completing military service in Germany. His mum, Kaati, said: We were surprised and beyond embarrassed. My husband and I were talking, which was our code word for sex when the kids were little, and we were in the moment when the door got kicked open. I screamed because I saw my son and of course realised he saw everything exposed. Josephaposs sister filmed her brotheraposs reaction to the whole thing, which has since been shared online and went viral. Do you have a story to share  We want to hear all about it. She said: “I love the attention – and I love giving my fans the attention too on Valentine’s Day. “I love Valentineaposs Day – I usually get an average of  messages from men on the day – along with cash gts ranging from - . “The most extravagant gt I’ve received on Valentine’s Day was a diamond necklace worth , , which I received by a fan who later became a partner. Nita is married to a man - who has remained anonymous for privacy reasons -  years her junior and says itaposs not unusual for her to receive messages and donations from younger men.  She added: “The average age of my fans is . I enjoy being an older woman that younger men find attractive because it reminds me to never forget about my own sexuality and the power of feeling good in my own skin – no matter what age! Itaposs fun to date younger men because they arenapost afraid to try new things. They have a high sex drive and keep things exciting in the bedroom. And despite being inundated with offers this Valentineaposs Day, Nita wonapost be giving in to any of the requests sheaposs received, as sheaposd much rather spend the holiday enjoying a quiet night in with her husband.  The model previously made headlines after claiming she and her husband have threesomes with God and while she says she invites the heavenly spirit to join her sex le multiple times a week, she hasnapost decided whether heaposll get to join in on February .Although he has never shown himself in a physical form, Nita says she can feel Godaposs presence in the room when she gets intimate with her husband. She previously said: “When you invite God to be a part of sex you change the act from something purely physical to something sacred and spiritual. “I’ve been asking him to join me and my husband since the very first time we made love. There is nothing more fulfilling or satisfying than when you experience God’s love for you while pleasuring your partner.”Have you got a story to share  We want to hear all about it. title: shoppers range spot hidden name
story: Shoppers at The Range spot hidden name in stores logo - and now they cant unsee itThe Range customers have uncovered a hidden message in the shops logo that they had no idea existed - and some are now convinced it has a completely dferent nameCan you see it  Image: Alamy Stock PhotoByZahna EklundAudience writer:,  Feb |commentsWho doesnapost love a shopping trip to The Range to completely re-stock your cushion collection, or snap up great deals on decorative storage containers that you hope will keep you organised The bargain retailer is a haven for all things home furnishings, but did you know that some people are convinced itaposs not called The Range at all  One woman noticed out the hidden message plastered on the outside of every one of the retaileraposs storefronts during a trip to her local Range - and now canapost stop referring to the shop as The Orange, thanks to the large orange-coloured circular logo that sits right next to the shopaposs name. The woman said on Facebook : So I blew my own mind today. I realised that The Range has an R in an orange circle as their logo, but I can’t unsee it as saying anything other than Orange now Get the news you want straight to your inbox.for a Mirror newsletter here. Has it been called The Orange all along and we’ve not noticed  Honestly, I am baffled. Someone please explain this to me and restore my faith in humanity. And the shopperaposs post left other fans of The Range equally as confused, as they admitted theyaposd never noticed the bizarre logo placement before and were now convinced the shop was supposed to be called The Orange. One person said: I see what you mean! Iaposve never noticed that before. While another added: Never noticed before but that’s now going to be stuck in my head.  And a third said: Now I only see it as Orange ... thataposs mad. But others said theyaposd actually started off by calling the shop by the wrong name when their local stores first opened, and had to be corrected by friends and family. Someone posted: I actually called the Range aposOrangeapos for the first few weeks after it opened until someone corrected me. Itaposs a bit of a rubbish logo!To put people out of their confused misery, The Range have since set the record straight over on their Instagram account, @therangeuk, where they insisted their official name has, and always will be, The Range.They said: We’ve received so many messages about this viral post. Itaposs taken you all a while to notice! We do love the colour O-Range but all jokes aside we are officially called aposThe Rangeapos. But in true British spirit, many shoppers have decided they donapost care what the official statement is - they much prefer calling the shop The Orange now. One said: Calling it The Range is old school. Itaposs The Orange for me from now on. As another wrote: Wait, what  Now I will only refer to it as Orange.What do you think of The Rangeaposs hidden name  Let us know in the comments below.Read MoreRead MoreMost Read Dont MissFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterComment MORE ON FacebookFunny ha ha viralViralUmm what " data-immediate"data-immediate" to FREE email alerts with news to brighten your daySubscribeInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. news weird-news woman-sick-cars-parking-across-"Woman exasperated by people blocking her drivewayByZahna EklundAudience writer:,  Feb |comments Thereaposs not much in le thataposs more annoying than drivers who inconvenience us.Whether itaposs overtaking when they shouldnapost, getting obnoxiously close to your car because they think youaposre not driving fast enough, or parking in the most bizarre of positions - there are a lot of things to get road rage over when it comes to being a motorist.But one woman has been left particularly infuriated by the drivers in her neighbourhood before sheaposs even managed to get out on the road herself because they keep parking on the dropped kerb outside her house and blocking her driveway. Sibongile Mude frequently takes to TikTok on her account, @sibs, to share videos from her bedroom window of the cars in question, and has even taken to sticking angry notes to their windows and windscreen in an attempt to dissuade the drivers from parking there again.Get the news you want straight to your inbox.for a Mirror newsletter here. In one clip, Sibongile showed off the note she writes up, which read: Your parking is NOT okay. You have blocked in my car - in my driveway! I am now stuck!! While another message written by the stressed homeowner read: You have parked in front of my driveway. I need to park MY CAR. Sibongile and her friends have even confronted some of the drivers who happen toto their vehicle while the woman is filming, with one woman caught on camera telling them her parking was not a big deal. Explaining what the woman had said, Sibongile wrote in the comments of one video: Whataposs said ... aposYouaposre blocking my carapos and she said, aposItaposs not much of a big dealapos and then she told her, to do one ... plus other words l can not say.  Sibongile even shared one video which showed three dferent cars parked across the exit to her driveway on three separate days, and explained that some of them are there for hours. She wrote in the comments: Itaposs annoying because you guys only see  seconds, but some of these guys park for  to  hours, and we need in and out of our driveway quite often. Commenters on the womanaposs videos have come up with a iety of solutions to her problem, including asking the council to paint lines on the road in front of her driveway or placing cones down to deter people from parking. One person said: You might have to cover some or all the cost but I’m sure the local council can authorise white lines to help people realise there’s access needed.  While another added: Canapost you put some cones down to stop people parking there  Is it illegal to park across a driveway  Parking across a driveway is only illegalthere is a dropped kerb, but this has nothing to do with the restriction of access to the driveway itself and is in place because dropped kerbs are a no-go for parking. Evena vehicle is only partially covering a dropped kerb, the owner will be committing a driving offence and could be liable to receive a penalty of up to three points and a fine of up to £. However, parking close to a dropped kerb is not illegal, eventhis restricts access to a driveway.According to Confused, police are unlikely to get involved in cases where the parking over the dropped kerb stops you from moving your vehicle into your driveway, butthe parking issue stops you from leaving they may treat it as an anti-social behaviour offence.Anti-social behaviour is defined by the Crime and Disorder Actas: “Acting in a manner that caused or was likely to cause harassment, alarm or distress to one or more persons not of the same household as the defendant.” Have you got a story to share  We want to hear all about it. title: family horrified after dna test
story: Family horried after DNA test shows adult IVF baby isn’t related to her dadThe Harveys have accused Summa Health System of malpractice, negligence and fraud, alleging the doctor and his health practice failed to “safeguard” John’s genetic materialJeanine and John have only recently discovered their daughter is not related to her dad Image: Harvey FamilyByAlice Peacock:,  Feb Updated:,  Feb |comments A family is suing their doctor after a DNA test showed their adult IVF baby isn’t related to her dad, prompting their claims that a stranger’s sperm was used in the  insemination.According to the lawsuit filed on Wednesday, Jeanine and John “Mike” Harvey said they discovered their daughter Jessica was not biologically related to her father following a DNA test. The family, from Ohio in the US, have accused Summa Health System of malpractice, negligence and fraud. The couple alleged the health practice failed to “properly collect” and “safeguard” John’s genetic material. Speaking in a virtual press conference, Jeanine said she and John had been to see a fertility doctor for help around  years ago. She claimed they “couldn’t have been clearer” in their goal, which was to have a child who was genetically related to both of them.  “I underwent the in vitro fertilisation with the understanding that Mike’s genetic materials would be used in this procedure,” she said. The family first learned of the alleged botched procedure upon purchasing a DNA test for Jessica, before she went to Europe in . Jeanine explained the family thought the it could be “cool” for her to connect with distant relatives in the countries she visited.  However, instead of her father’s Italian heritage on her test, Jessica instead found that she was of Irish, English, German, Welsh and French descent. Jessica said there were “no words” to express what she and her parents had been through and claimed she was in “total disbelief”. The organisation has made a statement to local media outlets saying it was taking the allegations “seriously”. “At this point, we have not met with the family or conducted testing of our own. Given the very limited information that we have and the amount of time that has passed, it remains our hope that the attorneys representing the family will work with us to make that next step a priority,” Mike Bernstein, system director of Corporate Communications for Summa Health System, said. Jessica had since tracked down her biological father through ancestry and genealogists hired by her lawyer. It has been confirmed that the man gave sperm for an insemination procedure on the same day the Harveys were in his office. The Harvey family have said they hope their lawsuit will lead to federal oversight of the fertility industry. title: fisherman almost loses hand propellor
story: Fisherman almost loses his hand in propellor in horric boating injuryWARNING - GRAPHIC IMAGES Alexey Barkhatov had gone ing with a friend when the horror accident happened while he was fishing with a spear at Sydney Harbour with his ing friendAlexey BarkhatovByGraeme Murray:,  Feb |commentsA fisherman almost lost his hand and suffered a horrying injury after being hit by a boater. Alexey Barkhatov was struck by a passing boat and its propeller left a gaping wound in his hand which needed hospital treatment. He had gone ing with a friend when the horror accident happened while he was fishing with a spear at Sydney Harbour, Australia. Alexey now wants the regulations on water routes to be changed after his brush with death which left him badly injured.He told Yahoo Australia : cm to the left and this boat could have killed me and my ing buddy,  I was with my ing buddy, really shallow with two floats, when he appeared out of nowhere, speeding. I tried to defend my hand with the gun and was able to e quickly but not as deep as I hoped. He regularly es where the the accident happened and says they have two very visible floats which can be seen from some distanceMr Barkhatov and his friend had been ing near Middle Head for a few hours when they spotted some fish and were preparing to target them when he suddenly heard a noise.There were boats nearby and after hearing the noise of an engine he ed quickly and defended himself with his spear gun.  He believes this saved his le when the boat hit him and its propeller caught the edge of his hand leaving badly wounded. He was covered with blood after arriving above the water and the boat drive helped him on board. They used a dogaposs lead to stem the blood while his ing partner called the maritime police and took them to shore where paramedics were waiting to take him to hospital.  Mr Barkhatovaposs endured three hours of surgery but doctors were luckily able to save his hand. Iaposm very lucky, he said. Thataposs why now Iaposm trying to find a way how to use my story to prevent such accidents in the future.The New South Wales government website says most water routes do not have have a limit for speed..It says: All vessels must travel at a safe speed at all times A safe speed gives you enough time to stop, or turn your vessel to avoid any sudden danger, such as a collision, injury to people, or damage to things. Mr Barkhatov called for the enforcement of speed limits and increased curbs for boats near swimmers and ers. He says buoys could show the boats where swimmers or other water users could be which he insists could save lives. title: stirling judges set for action as bull sales kick back after covid
story: We are excited to announce a new home for the Eveningcontent online, with a bigger and better website in partnership with The Courier. We have spoken to our readers, and our aim is to deliver you everything that you need to know, together in one place.If you are a subscriber or thinking about joining our digital community, find out what it means for you below.In order to give you access to the news that you need, we have expanded our newsrooms and created dedicated news teams to serve you and our extended local communities across Tayside and Fe. We will deliver you more content, live news as it happens, as well as breaking crime news and the latest from court, together in one place. We have also found new ways of telling our stories online, from in-depth investigations through to full- documentaries and podcasts.There is no change to The Courier and the Eveningnewspaper or ePapers. title: george lyon gene editing is vital to help start new green revolution
story: We are excited to announce a new home for the Evening Express content online, with a bigger and better website in partnership with The Press and Journal. We have spoken to our readers, and our aim is to deliver you everything that you need to know, together in one place.If you are a subscriber or thinking about joining our digital community, find out what it means for you below.In order to give you access to the news that you need, we have expanded our newsrooms and created dedicated news teams to serve you and our extended local communities across Aberdeen, Aberdeenshire, the Highlands and Islands and the North and North-East of Scotland. We will deliver you more content, live news as it happens, as well as breaking crime news and the latest from court, together in one place. We have also found new ways of telling our stories online, from in-depth investigations through to full- documentaries and podcasts.There is no change to The Press and Journal and the Evening Express newspaper or ePapers. The newspapers will continue to be available for purchase at your local store, delivered to your home, or as an ePaper . We will continue to deliver you the best stories in print, that you have come to expect from the PJ and the Evening Express.Our ePapers are a full replica version of the newspaper, published online,  days a week. You can access the PJ and the Evening Express ePaper via our dedicated ePaper apps where you can save and share stories, access all the paper supplements easily via their dedicated menu and even play interactive puzzles!If you would like to find out more about subscribing to the PJ or the Evening Express ePaper, please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team on Your subscription to the Press and Journal will allow you to access all of the Evening Express stories which are now available on the PJ website. All of the best Evening Express content, including columnists and football analysis will now appear on the PJ website and will be available for you as part of your subscription.If you have an ePaper subscription there will be no change as to how you access your Press and Journal ePaper.The new website is now live. Evening Express content can now be found on The Press and Journal website.When you purchased your subscription an email was sent to your account with your login details. To reset your password please use the following link.Please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team, on  Monday # Friday, am # pm, or email.Your subscription will continue as normal and all your existing subscriber benefits will remain in place. There are changes as to how you access your subscription benefits. See below, depending on what type of subscription you have.If you are an existing Evening Express Web subscriber, you can log in to your account as normal through The Press and Journal website.If you have an ePaper subscription you can access your ePaper on The Press and Journal website here.Or via a new link in your Daily ePaper email.There is no change to your reoccurring billing agreement. If you purchase a new subscription through The PJ website the price is subject to change and may be more than your current subscription. If you have any questions about your current subscription or how to access your subscription benefits in the future, please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team, on   Monday # Friday, am # pm, or email.The new website is now live. Evening Express content can now be found on The Press and Journal website.Your subscription will continue as normal and all your existing subscriber benefits will remain in place.You can access your ePaper on The Press and Journal website here.Or via a new link in your Daily ePaper email.If you have any questions about your current subscription or how to access your subscription benefits in the future, please contact our Digital News Subscription Team   , or email.Yes, we will still send you a daily ePaper reminder with a link to the Evening Express ePaper, every time there is a new ePaper available .No, the Evening Express ePaper app will remain exactly the same.If you are an existing Evening Express Web subscriber, you can log in to your account as normal through the PJ website here.If you have an ePaper subscription you can access your ePaper on the PJ website here.Or via a new link in your Daily ePaper email.Yes, your existing Evening Express login details work on The Press and Journal. To log in please visit www.pressandjournal login.If you have any problems logging in, please contact our Digital News Subscription Team on  , or email.When you purchased your subscription, an email was sent to your account with your login details. To reset your password please use the following link.No, your existing reoccurring billing agreement will not change. If you cancel this agreement you can still purchase a new subscription in the future through The Press and Journal website. The price is subject to change and may be more than your current subscription.If you have any questions about your current subscription or how to access your subscription benefits in the future, please contact our Digital News Subscription Team   , or email.Please contact our Digital News Subscription Team on    Monday # Friday, am # pm, or email.The Evening Express website is no longer available. If you navigate to the Evening Express website or have website links saved, you will be automatically redirected to The Press and Journal website.Yes. You will find all the content that you would have normally found at the Evening Express here.Our combined newsroom will deliver you all of the Evening Express content that you would expect from The Evening Express website, plus more! We will continue to bring you the very best local news, football insight and in-depth features, as well as your favourite Evening Express columnists. These can all be found on The Press and Journal website as well as live news # updated as it happens # breaking crime news and the latest from court. You can also find our very best content that was published originally on the Evening Express website. These articles will be marked as originally appearing on the Evening Express website.Some Evening Express content will be moved to The Press and Journal website. Your bookmarked links will automatically redirect to the corresponding page on The Press and Journal website.Yes, The Press and Journal and the Evening Express social pages will continue. We will curate content specically for our audiences through our Facebook, Twitter and Instagram channels. All articles will link to The PJ website.Your registration details that you set up on the Evening Express website will work on The Press and Journal website. Please log in to your account as normal via the top right hand corner of the website or with this link.If you have forgotten your login or password please click the password reset link and follow the instructions.Yes. All registered users can access  free articlesevery  days. Please note, this information is correct at the time of publication, however, DC Thomson reserve the right to change this in the future.No, you will no longer receive Evening Express branded newsletters. You will now receive Press and Journal newsletters. If you do not wish to receive these, click the #unsubscribe# link at the bottom of the newsletter email.The Press and Journal has a Web subscription available which will give you access to all content on site from The Press and Journal and the Evening Express. You can purchase a PJ Web or PJ ePaper subscription here: www.pressandjournal subscribeThe Evening Express ePaper subscription is still available for purchase here.If you need help deciding what subscription is best for you, our Digital News Subscriptions Team are standing by to help. Please call on    Monday # Friday, am # pm, or email.No, there is only one Web subscription available on The Press and Journal. The Press and Journal Web subscription will give you access to all content on site from The PJ and the Evening Express. You can purchase a Press and Journal Web or Press and Journal ePaper subscription here.If you have an existing Evening Express Web subscription then all your subscription benefits are now available on The Press and Journal site. You have access to a bigger and better website, with all your favourite Evening Express content plus more.If you need help deciding what subscription is best for you, our Digital News Subscriptions Team are standing by to help. Please call on    Monday # Friday, am # pm, or email.You can purchase an Evening Express ePaper subscription here.Yes, you can. Our ePapers are an exact digital replica of the newspaper and carry unique content in both titles. title: stirling judges set for action as bull sales kick back after covid
story: We are excited to announce a new home for the Evening Express content online, with a bigger and better website in partnership with The Press and Journal. We have spoken to our readers, and our aim is to deliver you everything that you need to know, together in one place.If you are a subscriber or thinking about joining our digital community, find out what it means for you below.In order to give you access to the news that you need, we have expanded our newsrooms and created dedicated news teams to serve you and our extended local communities across Aberdeen, Aberdeenshire, the Highlands and Islands and the North and North-East of Scotland. We will deliver you more content, live news as it happens, as well as breaking crime news and the latest from court, together in one place. We have also found new ways of telling our stories online, from in-depth investigations through to full- documentaries and podcasts.There is no change to The Press and Journal and the Evening Express newspaper or ePapers. The newspapers will continue to be available for purchase at your local store, delivered to your home, or as an ePaper . We will continue to deliver you the best stories in print, that you have come to expect from the PJ and the Evening Express.Our ePapers are a full replica version of the newspaper, published online,  days a week. You can access the PJ and the Evening Express ePaper via our dedicated ePaper apps where you can save and share stories, access all the paper supplements easily via their dedicated menu and even play interactive puzzles!If you would like to find out more about subscribing to the PJ or the Evening Express ePaper, please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team on Your subscription to the Press and Journal will allow you to access all of the Evening Express stories which are now available on the PJ website. All of the best Evening Express content, including columnists and football analysis will now appear on the PJ website and will be available for you as part of your subscription.If you have an ePaper subscription there will be no change as to how you access your Press and Journal ePaper.The new website is now live. Evening Express content can now be found on The Press and Journal website.When you purchased your subscription an email was sent to your account with your login details. To reset your password please use the following link.Please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team, on  Monday # Friday, am # pm, or email.Your subscription will continue as normal and all your existing subscriber benefits will remain in place. There are changes as to how you access your subscription benefits. See below, depending on what type of subscription you have.If you are an existing Evening Express Web subscriber, you can log in to your account as normal through The Press and Journal website.If you have an ePaper subscription you can access your ePaper on The Press and Journal website here.Or via a new link in your Daily ePaper email.There is no change to your reoccurring billing agreement. If you purchase a new subscription through The PJ website the price is subject to change and may be more than your current subscription. If you have any questions about your current subscription or how to access your subscription benefits in the future, please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team, on   Monday # Friday, am # pm, or email.The new website is now live. Evening Express content can now be found on The Press and Journal website.Your subscription will continue as normal and all your existing subscriber benefits will remain in place.You can access your ePaper on The Press and Journal website here.Or via a new link in your Daily ePaper email.If you have any questions about your current subscription or how to access your subscription benefits in the future, please contact our Digital News Subscription Team   , or email.Yes, we will still send you a daily ePaper reminder with a link to the Evening Express ePaper, every time there is a new ePaper available .No, the Evening Express ePaper app will remain exactly the same.If you are an existing Evening Express Web subscriber, you can log in to your account as normal through the PJ website here.If you have an ePaper subscription you can access your ePaper on the PJ website here.Or via a new link in your Daily ePaper email.Yes, your existing Evening Express login details work on The Press and Journal. To log in please visit www.pressandjournal login.If you have any problems logging in, please contact our Digital News Subscription Team on  , or email.When you purchased your subscription, an email was sent to your account with your login details. To reset your password please use the following link.No, your existing reoccurring billing agreement will not change. If you cancel this agreement you can still purchase a new subscription in the future through The Press and Journal website. The price is subject to change and may be more than your current subscription.If you have any questions about your current subscription or how to access your subscription benefits in the future, please contact our Digital News Subscription Team   , or email.Please contact our Digital News Subscription Team on    Monday # Friday, am # pm, or email.The Evening Express website is no longer available. If you navigate to the Evening Express website or have website links saved, you will be automatically redirected to The Press and Journal website.Yes. You will find all the content that you would have normally found at the Evening Express here.Our combined newsroom will deliver you all of the Evening Express content that you would expect from The Evening Express website, plus more! We will continue to bring you the very best local news, football insight and in-depth features, as well as your favourite Evening Express columnists. These can all be found on The Press and Journal website as well as live news # updated as it happens # breaking crime news and the latest from court. You can also find our very best content that was published originally on the Evening Express website. These articles will be marked as originally appearing on the Evening Express website.Some Evening Express content will be moved to The Press and Journal website. Your bookmarked links will automatically redirect to the corresponding page on The Press and Journal website.Yes, The Press and Journal and the Evening Express social pages will continue. We will curate content specically for our audiences through our Facebook, Twitter and Instagram channels. All articles will link to The PJ website.Your registration details that you set up on the Evening Express website will work on The Press and Journal website. Please log in to your account as normal via the top right hand corner of the website or with this link.If you have forgotten your login or password please click the password reset link and follow the instructions.Yes. All registered users can access  free articlesevery  days. Please note, this information is correct at the time of publication, however, DC Thomson reserve the right to change this in the future.No, you will no longer receive Evening Express branded newsletters. You will now receive Press and Journal newsletters. If you do not wish to receive these, click the #unsubscribe# link at the bottom of the newsletter email.The Press and Journal has a Web subscription available which will give you access to all content on site from The Press and Journal and the Evening Express. You can purchase a PJ Web or PJ ePaper subscription here: www.pressandjournal subscribeThe Evening Express ePaper subscription is still available for purchase here.If you need help deciding what subscription is best for you, our Digital News Subscriptions Team are standing by to help. Please call on    Monday # Friday, am # pm, or email.No, there is only one Web subscription available on The Press and Journal. The Press and Journal Web subscription will give you access to all content on site from The PJ and the Evening Express. You can purchase a Press and Journal Web or Press and Journal ePaper subscription here.If you have an existing Evening Express Web subscription then all your subscription benefits are now available on The Press and Journal site. You have access to a bigger and better website, with all your favourite Evening Express content plus more.If you need help deciding what subscription is best for you, our Digital News Subscriptions Team are standing by to help. Please call on    Monday # Friday, am # pm, or email.You can purchase an Evening Express ePaper subscription here.Yes, you can. Our ePapers are an exact digital replica of the newspaper and carry unique content in both titles. title: quality meat scotland high quality meat deserves a place at the table of the future as consumers look to mindful eating
story: We are excited to announce a new home for the Evening Express content online, with a bigger and better website in partnership with The Press and Journal. We have spoken to our readers, and our aim is to deliver you everything that you need to know, together in one place.If you are a subscriber or thinking about joining our digital community, find out what it means for you below.In order to give you access to the news that you need, we have expanded our newsrooms and created dedicated news teams to serve you and our extended local communities across Aberdeen, Aberdeenshire, the Highlands and Islands and the North and North-East of Scotland. We will deliver you more content, live news as it happens, as well as breaking crime news and the latest from court, together in one place. We have also found new ways of telling our stories online, from in-depth investigations through to full- documentaries and podcasts.There is no change to The Press and Journal and the Evening Express newspaper or ePapers. The newspapers will continue to be available for purchase at your local store, delivered to your home, or as an ePaper . We will continue to deliver you the best stories in print, that you have come to expect from the PJ and the Evening Express.Our ePapers are a full replica version of the newspaper, published online,  days a week. You can access the PJ and the Evening Express ePaper via our dedicated ePaper apps where you can save and share stories, access all the paper supplements easily via their dedicated menu and even play interactive puzzles!If you would like to find out more about subscribing to the PJ or the Evening Express ePaper, please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team on Your subscription to the Press and Journal will allow you to access all of the Evening Express stories which are now available on the PJ website. All of the best Evening Express content, including columnists and football analysis will now appear on the PJ website and will be available for you as part of your subscription.If you have an ePaper subscription there will be no change as to how you access your Press and Journal ePaper.The new website is now live. Evening Express content can now be found on The Press and Journal website.When you purchased your subscription an email was sent to your account with your login details. To reset your password please use the following link.Please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team, on  Monday # Friday, am # pm, or email.Your subscription will continue as normal and all your existing subscriber benefits will remain in place. There are changes as to how you access your subscription benefits. See below, depending on what type of subscription you have.If you are an existing Evening Express Web subscriber, you can log in to your account as normal through The Press and Journal website.If you have an ePaper subscription you can access your ePaper on The Press and Journal website here.Or via a new link in your Daily ePaper email.There is no change to your reoccurring billing agreement. If you purchase a new subscription through The PJ website the price is subject to change and may be more than your current subscription. If you have any questions about your current subscription or how to access your subscription benefits in the future, please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team, on   Monday # Friday, am # pm, or email.The new website is now live. Evening Express content can now be found on The Press and Journal website.Your subscription will continue as normal and all your existing subscriber benefits will remain in place.You can access your ePaper on The Press and Journal website here.Or via a new link in your Daily ePaper email.If you have any questions about your current subscription or how to access your subscription benefits in the future, please contact our Digital News Subscription Team   , or email.Yes, we will still send you a daily ePaper reminder with a link to the Evening Express ePaper, every time there is a new ePaper available .No, the Evening Express ePaper app will remain exactly the same.If you are an existing Evening Express Web subscriber, you can log in to your account as normal through the PJ website here.If you have an ePaper subscription you can access your ePaper on the PJ website here.Or via a new link in your Daily ePaper email.Yes, your existing Evening Express login details work on The Press and Journal. To log in please visit www.pressandjournal login.If you have any problems logging in, please contact our Digital News Subscription Team on  , or email.When you purchased your subscription, an email was sent to your account with your login details. To reset your password please use the following link.No, your existing reoccurring billing agreement will not change. If you cancel this agreement you can still purchase a new subscription in the future through The Press and Journal website. The price is subject to change and may be more than your current subscription.If you have any questions about your current subscription or how to access your subscription benefits in the future, please contact our Digital News Subscription Team   , or email.Please contact our Digital News Subscription Team on    Monday # Friday, am # pm, or email.The Evening Express website is no longer available. If you navigate to the Evening Express website or have website links saved, you will be automatically redirected to The Press and Journal website.Yes. You will find all the content that you would have normally found at the Evening Express here.Our combined newsroom will deliver you all of the Evening Express content that you would expect from The Evening Express website, plus more! We will continue to bring you the very best local news, football insight and in-depth features, as well as your favourite Evening Express columnists. These can all be found on The Press and Journal website as well as live news # updated as it happens # breaking crime news and the latest from court. You can also find our very best content that was published originally on the Evening Express website. These articles will be marked as originally appearing on the Evening Express website.Some Evening Express content will be moved to The Press and Journal website. Your bookmarked links will automatically redirect to the corresponding page on The Press and Journal website.Yes, The Press and Journal and the Evening Express social pages will continue. We will curate content specically for our audiences through our Facebook, Twitter and Instagram channels. All articles will link to The PJ website.Your registration details that you set up on the Evening Express website will work on The Press and Journal website. Please log in to your account as normal via the top right hand corner of the website or with this link.If you have forgotten your login or password please click the password reset link and follow the instructions.Yes. All registered users can access  free articlesevery  days. Please note, this information is correct at the time of publication, however, DC Thomson reserve the right to change this in the future.No, you will no longer receive Evening Express branded newsletters. You will now receive Press and Journal newsletters. If you do not wish to receive these, click the #unsubscribe# link at the bottom of the newsletter email.The Press and Journal has a Web subscription available which will give you access to all content on site from The Press and Journal and the Evening Express. You can purchase a PJ Web or PJ ePaper subscription here: www.pressandjournal subscribeThe Evening Express ePaper subscription is still available for purchase here.If you need help deciding what subscription is best for you, our Digital News Subscriptions Team are standing by to help. Please call on    Monday # Friday, am # pm, or email.No, there is only one Web subscription available on The Press and Journal. The Press and Journal Web subscription will give you access to all content on site from The PJ and the Evening Express. You can purchase a Press and Journal Web or Press and Journal ePaper subscription here.If you have an existing Evening Express Web subscription then all your subscription benefits are now available on The Press and Journal site. You have access to a bigger and better website, with all your favourite Evening Express content plus more.If you need help deciding what subscription is best for you, our Digital News Subscriptions Team are standing by to help. Please call on    Monday # Friday, am # pm, or email.You can purchase an Evening Express ePaper subscription here.Yes, you can. Our ePapers are an exact digital replica of the newspaper and carry unique content in both titles. story: We are excited to announce a new home for the Evening Express content online, with a bigger and better website in partnership with The Press and Journal. We have spoken to our readers, and our aim is to deliver you everything that you need to know, together in one place.If you are a subscriber or thinking about joining our digital community, find out what it means for you below.In order to give you access to the news that you need, we have expanded our newsrooms and created dedicated news teams to serve you and our extended local communities across Aberdeen, Aberdeenshire, the Highlands and Islands and the North and North-East of Scotland. We will deliver you more content, live news as it happens, as well as breaking crime news and the latest from court, together in one place. We have also found new ways of telling our stories online, from in-depth investigations through to full- documentaries and podcasts.There is no change to The Press and Journal and the Evening Express newspaper or ePapers. The newspapers will continue to be available for purchase at your local store, delivered to your home, or as an ePaper . We will continue to deliver you the best stories in print, that you have come to expect from the PJ and the Evening Express.Our ePapers are a full replica version of the newspaper, published online,  days a week. You can access the PJ and the Evening Express ePaper via our dedicated ePaper apps where you can save and share stories, access all the paper supplements easily via their dedicated menu and even play interactive puzzles!If you would like to find out more about subscribing to the PJ or the Evening Express ePaper, please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team on Your subscription to the Press and Journal will allow you to access all of the Evening Express stories which are now available on the PJ website. All of the best Evening Express content, including columnists and football analysis will now appear on the PJ website and will be available for you as part of your subscription.If you have an ePaper subscription there will be no change as to how you access your Press and Journal ePaper.The new website is now live. Evening Express content can now be found on The Press and Journal website.When you purchased your subscription an email was sent to your account with your login details. To reset your password please use the following link.Please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team, on  Monday # Friday, am # pm, or email.Your subscription will continue as normal and all your existing subscriber benefits will remain in place. There are changes as to how you access your subscription benefits. See below, depending on what type of subscription you have.If you are an existing Evening Express Web subscriber, you can log in to your account as normal through The Press and Journal website.If you have an ePaper subscription you can access your ePaper on The Press and Journal website here.Or via a new link in your Daily ePaper email.There is no change to your reoccurring billing agreement. If you purchase a new subscription through The PJ website the price is subject to change and may be more than your current subscription. If you have any questions about your current subscription or how to access your subscription benefits in the future, please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team, on   Monday # Friday, am # pm, or email.The new website is now live. Evening Express content can now be found on The Press and Journal website.Your subscription will continue as normal and all your existing subscriber benefits will remain in place.You can access your ePaper on The Press and Journal website here.Or via a new link in your Daily ePaper email.If you have any questions about your current subscription or how to access your subscription benefits in the future, please contact our Digital News Subscription Team   , or email.Yes, we will still send you a daily ePaper reminder with a link to the Evening Express ePaper, every time there is a new ePaper available .No, the Evening Express ePaper app will remain exactly the same.If you are an existing Evening Express Web subscriber, you can log in to your account as normal through the PJ website here.If you have an ePaper subscription you can access your ePaper on the PJ website here.Or via a new link in your Daily ePaper email.Yes, your existing Evening Express login details work on The Press and Journal. To log in please visit www.pressandjournal login.If you have any problems logging in, please contact our Digital News Subscription Team on  , or email.When you purchased your subscription, an email was sent to your account with your login details. To reset your password please use the following link.No, your existing reoccurring billing agreement will not change. If you cancel this agreement you can still purchase a new subscription in the future through The Press and Journal website. The price is subject to change and may be more than your current subscription.If you have any questions about your current subscription or how to access your subscription benefits in the future, please contact our Digital News Subscription Team   , or email.Please contact our Digital News Subscription Team on    Monday # Friday, am # pm, or email.The Evening Express website is no longer available. If you navigate to the Evening Express website or have website links saved, you will be automatically redirected to The Press and Journal website.Yes. You will find all the content that you would have normally found at the Evening Express here.Our combined newsroom will deliver you all of the Evening Express content that you would expect from The Evening Express website, plus more! We will continue to bring you the very best local news, football insight and in-depth features, as well as your favourite Evening Express columnists. These can all be found on The Press and Journal website as well as live news # updated as it happens # breaking crime news and the latest from court. You can also find our very best content that was published originally on the Evening Express website. These articles will be marked as originally appearing on the Evening Express website.Some Evening Express content will be moved to The Press and Journal website. Your bookmarked links will automatically redirect to the corresponding page on The Press and Journal website.Yes, The Press and Journal and the Evening Express social pages will continue. We will curate content specically for our audiences through our Facebook, Twitter and Instagram channels. All articles will link to The PJ website.Your registration details that you set up on the Evening Express website will work on The Press and Journal website. Please log in to your account as normal via the top right hand corner of the website or with this link.If you have forgotten your login or password please click the password reset link and follow the instructions.Yes. All registered users can access  free articlesevery  days. Please note, this information is correct at the time of publication, however, DC Thomson reserve the right to change this in the future.No, you will no longer receive Evening Express branded newsletters. You will now receive Press and Journal newsletters. If you do not wish to receive these, click the #unsubscribe# link at the bottom of the newsletter email.The Press and Journal has a Web subscription available which will give you access to all content on site from The Press and Journal and the Evening Express. You can purchase a PJ Web or PJ ePaper subscription here: www.pressandjournal subscribeThe Evening Express ePaper subscription is still available for purchase here.If you need help deciding what subscription is best for you, our Digital News Subscriptions Team are standing by to help. Please call on    Monday # Friday, am # pm, or email.No, there is only one Web subscription available on The Press and Journal. The Press and Journal Web subscription will give you access to all content on site from The PJ and the Evening Express. You can purchase a Press and Journal Web or Press and Journal ePaper subscription here.If you have an existing Evening Express Web subscription then all your subscription benefits are now available on The Press and Journal site. You have access to a bigger and better website, with all your favourite Evening Express content plus more.If you need help deciding what subscription is best for you, our Digital News Subscriptions Team are standing by to help. Please call on    Monday # Friday, am # pm, or email.You can purchase an Evening Express ePaper subscription here.Yes, you can. Our ePapers are an exact digital replica of the newspaper and carry unique content in both titles. title: 36000 spent so far on co2 meters and ventilation improvements in moray schools
story: We are excited to announce a new home for the Evening Express content online, with a bigger and better website in partnership with The Press and Journal. We have spoken to our readers, and our aim is to deliver you everything that you need to know, together in one place.If you are a subscriber or thinking about joining our digital community, find out what it means for you below.In order to give you access to the news that you need, we have expanded our newsrooms and created dedicated news teams to serve you and our extended local communities across Aberdeen, Aberdeenshire, the Highlands and Islands and the North and North-East of Scotland. We will deliver you more content, live news as it happens, as well as breaking crime news and the latest from court, together in one place. We have also found new ways of telling our stories online, from in-depth investigations through to full- documentaries and podcasts.There is no change to The Press and Journal and the Evening Express newspaper or ePapers. The newspapers will continue to be available for purchase at your local store, delivered to your home, or as an ePaper . We will continue to deliver you the best stories in print, that you have come to expect from the PJ and the Evening Express.Our ePapers are a full replica version of the newspaper, published online,  days a week. You can access the PJ and the Evening Express ePaper via our dedicated ePaper apps where you can save and share stories, access all the paper supplements easily via their dedicated menu and even play interactive puzzles!If you would like to find out more about subscribing to the PJ or the Evening Express ePaper, please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team on Your subscription to the Press and Journal will allow you to access all of the Evening Express stories which are now available on the PJ website. All of the best Evening Express content, including columnists and football analysis will now appear on the PJ website and will be available for you as part of your subscription.If you have an ePaper subscription there will be no change as to how you access your Press and Journal ePaper.The new website is now live. Evening Express content can now be found on The Press and Journal website.When you purchased your subscription an email was sent to your account with your login details. To reset your password please use the following link.Please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team, on  Monday # Friday, am # pm, or email.Your subscription will continue as normal and all your existing subscriber benefits will remain in place. There are changes as to how you access your subscription benefits.
