title: Ballynahinch U
story: BALLYNAHINCH U-s came up short in their quest for silverware as they failed to turn their early domination into points against a big physical Lurgan side in front of a good crowd at a blustery Ballymacarn Park.They dominated the opening quarter, but were guilty of overplaying in tricky conditions and failed to get on the scoreboard.Lurgan scored with their first attack following an excellent tap-and-go penalty from within their own half. They went through a few phases, allowing their out half to burst through a couple of tackles to score and take a - half time lead.Playing with the conditions in the second half, Ballynahinch started the on the front foot but fell foul of the referee at the breakdown, allowing Lurgan to pin them back in their own .The visiting forwards then went to work, carrying hard and scoring another try.The conversion left the home side  points down, but they hit back almost immediately with some great attacking rugby creating space for Callum McCargo to smash his way over.The game was on the line at this point, but a lack of composure allowed the excellent Lurgan full back to punish weak tackling and score a long range try.Left with a mountain to climb, Ballynahinch once again played some superb rugby with great interplay between centres James Graham and Harvey Campbell creating space for Sam Hamilton to dash for the line.He was stopped short but desperate Lurgan defending saw them receive a yellow card before Matthew McAuley reduced the deficit to five points with a try from a quickly taken penalty.A smash-and-grab victory against  men with only a minute on the clock demanded error-free rugby and after an excellent restart Ballynahinch moved upfield.However a knock-on saw the referee blow his whistle for full time and Lurgan earned a deserved victory.Both sides can be proud and the game was played in a superb spirit with the teams having lunch together in the clubhouse..prettyPhoto

title: Beauty of local landscapes feature in exploration events
story: SEVERAL familiar locations in Downpatrick, Newcastle and Strangford are at the heart of this monthrsquos Northern Ireland Science Festival.There will be a selection of events between February  and  with people across the district encouraged to explore something new as ious venues prepare to play host to a series of stirring events.The so-called STEM celebration mdash which has grown to become the largest of its kind in Ireland mdash boasts more than  events over  days.On February , the St Patrick Centre in Downpatrick is the venue for the Patrick  The Pagan Hills event which provides an opportunity to follow in the footsteps of both the patron saint and pagan in an exploration of the landscape that Patrick himself encountered when he ed to Ireland nearly , years ago.On February  and , the Strangford Activity Centre is hosting a ldquopaddle back in time kayak adventure to Mahee Island following a traditional smuggling route undertaken by Daft Eddie and the Merry Hearts.There will also be an opportunity to discover ruins of the monastic site of Nendrum, le in the monastery in the Middle Ages and the role played by the Vikings in the Strangford Lough area between the th and th centuries.The Strangford Activity Centre is also hosting ldquopaddle with a purpose on February  and  with participants invited to do their bit for the environment by joining a clean-up of Strangford Lough.And ldquoforaging afloat on February  and  at the same venue sees people joining with the Centrersquos Rory Martin and Andrea and Graham Gannon of Peninsula Kelp for a unique guide to the sights and flavour of the area as spring arrives on the lough and with it an array of seasonal wild food.On February , therersquos an opportunity to discover the wonders of the Mournes at a range of festival events.During the Diamond Rock Walking Tour on February , guide Peter Rafferty will explains how to identy erse rock types and how the Mournes were formed, alongside learning about the amazing geology and history of the area at the Geology on the Rocks event on February .The following day, the Men of Mourne ndash Stone  Steel hiking tour takes place with an opportunity to hear stories of hardship and endurance as participants take to rocky mountain tracks.During the Mourne Stone Walling ndash A Granite Kingdom event, therersquos a chance to experience the beauty and hard graft behind the ,-year-old craft of dry-stone wall building. A date for the event has yet to be confirmed.On February  at the Newcastle Community Cinema, Film Hub NI is inviting families to a special screening of lsquoThe Snail and the Whalersquo, a joyous, empowering story about the natural wonders of the world and discovering that no matter how small you are, you can make a dference.And to coincide with this special screening, NI Science Festival has organised an interactive seashore adventure with Beach Schools NI which will take place a short walk from the cinema and is included in the ticket price.Festival director, Chris McCreery, said the event exists to engage audiences, stimulate discussion, and ignite interest in the wonders of science, technology, engineering and mathematics.ldquoWe are confident that this yearrsquos erse programming will expand the horizons of festival goers of all ages and abilities across Northern Ireland, he added.The Science Festival is supported by the Department for the Economy, Belfast City Council, Tourism NI, Derry City and Strabane Council, Queenrsquos University,Ulster University, British Council Northern Ireland, MCS Group, The Open University NI, Innovate UK, Matrix NI, Film Hub NI and Arts and Business NI..prettyPhoto

title: From the pages of the Down Recorder%2C  February 5%2C 1992
story: DOWNPATRICK ndash The Downe Hospital has been identied as the possible site of a new police station in Downpatrick.The Police Authority has expressed an interest in the large site in a move which would pave the way for the construction of a new Downe Hospital, utilising Lecale House and the Maternity Hospital as the core buildings on the Ardglass Road.The present Downe Hospital, medical assessment unit and nurses home would then be completely demolished to make way for a new police base.Police Authority officials toured the hospital complex before Christmas and are reported to be impressed with both the size of the site and its central location.The officials have also held informal discussions with representatives of the Eastern Health Board who are also believed to be attracted to the plan.The revenue generated by the sale of the massive complex would go a long way to paying for the construction of a new hospital which politicians have called for on numerous occasions.A spokeswoman for the Police Authority said it is not normal policy to comment on such matters, and she added that there is still a commitment to build a new police base on the Ballydugan Road.Although the Authority has obtained outline planning permission for the Ballydugan Road site, it is believed that the nature of the land and the potential size of the highly fortied station is causing concern.Publicly the Authority is pressing ahead with plans to build there, but behind the scenes it has continued to look at possible sites in ious town locations.The Downe Hospital has now emerged as the surprise front-runner although evensuch an ambitious plan is approved, it will be many years before a police station is operational on the site.ARDGLASS ndash A special sub-committee has been set up by Down District Council to consider the European Communityrsquos review of the common fisheries policy.The committee is to be empowered to provide a response to the document.Ardglass SDLP councillor, Mr Dermot Curran, said some of the systems that were being introduced by the EC are not very helpful to the people employed in the fishing industry. Others were, such as decommissioning, but are not being put into action.ldquoIn all of these schemes there is nothing to protect the people employed in the industry. Government must do something to help the plight of these people, said Mr Curran.He complained that these workers are treated as casual labour with no claim to redundancy or national assistance.ldquoThe fishing industry plays a very important part in the economy of Northern Ireland and we must protect it and the people who work in it. Government should set up systems to ensure that everybody is treated fairly, he said.Ulster Unionist, Mr Gerry Douglas, said something has to be done to assist and to at least ensure that the processing industry is retained in Down District.KILLINCHY ndash The  new jobs announced by the Northern Ireland Spinners group as part of a pound.m investment will have no direct impact on its Killinchy factory.A spokesman for the company explained following Thursdayrsquos official announcement that the expansion of the firmrsquos sister factory in Newtownards will have no adverse impact on the Killinchy operation.ldquoThey are sister factories, both concentrating on very similar yarns, he said.ldquoWe have already completed major expansions at Killinchy, virtually replacing all the machinery we had. Killinchy is a very modern mill, as modern as Newtownards, he added.Mr Ray Dinsdale, chief executive of Richards Plc, the Aberdeen-based parent company of Northern Ireland Spinners, said: ldquoThis investment will strengthen the position of Northern Ireland Spinners as the largest United Kingdom spinner of semi-worsted yarns for carpet manufacturers.ldquoOur strategy is based on the expansion of the business into Europe, and the investment will mean that Northern Ireland Spinners will be of the size required to enable it to offer the economies of scale and cost reductions which are required to win business from major carpet manufacturers in these competitive markets, added Mr Dinsdale.CROSSGAR ndash Crossgarrsquos loss has been Bangorrsquos gain with a -job factory picking up an important quality certication.The firm of Dunn and CompanyLtd. was set up in Crossgar in , and it has now picked up the BS quality certication.After four years of trading, the company relocated from its premises in Crossgar to a factory unit based in Balloo industrial estate, Bangor.It manufacturers special purpose valves and precision components for industrial application with  per cent of it business going to the export market.It currently employs  people and has plans for further expansion, explained Mr Ron Dunn, managing director.When asked why the company left Crossgar, Mr Ron Dunn, managing director said: ldquoThere was not enough room in Crossgar.ldquoWe occupied part of the premises of my brother, Sam, but there was just nothing available in the Crossgar area at that time when we employed three of four people.His brother continues his own successful firm manufacturing machine tools on the Saintfield Road, Crossgar.BISHOPSCOURT ndash Planning Service officials have been urged to attend next monthrsquos first bike race at the former Bishopscourt base ndash before reaching a decision on a planning application for a permanent circuit.The plea has been made this week by local SDLP councillor, Mr John Ritchie.ldquoI would expect they will understand the necessity to attend to make an informed judgement on the matter, explained Mr Ritchie.ldquoAfter that date I would hope a decision would not be long delayed.Mr Ritchie said he had read the petition against the proposed race track and seen the comments of those members of the Ballyhornan Development Association who support the proposal. He had also read the details given by the two developers.ldquoThere are a number of issues involved. I understand that there can be up to  meetings without planning permission per year the equivalent of one a month and two a month in two summer months. I would have thought this wasnrsquot unreasonable.SAINTFIELD ndash The centre of Saintfield was sealed off for three hours on Friday afternoon after the discovery of a suspicious package in a telephone box.The area around Crossgar Road and Toddrsquos Hill was closed as army bomb disposal experts carried out an examination of the device.The device which consisted of cassettes, a battery pack and wires, was described as an elaborate hoax and was taken away for examination.NEWCASTLE ndash Mentally handicapped people from all over Northern Ireland will soon be benefitting from a remarkable transformation at Newcastlersquos Ruby House.For the past year passers-by have seen the conversion of the Bryansford Road complex from a row of not-so-attractive seaside resort houses into aspacious and modern residential home which now offers accommodation for  mentally handicapped adults.This year the holiday home is expected to provide upwards of  holidays for mentally handicapped people from all over the Province.The Ruby House Group now has three centres in Newcastle, including a converted house in Main Street and the purpose-built Mary Murray House in the Lawnfield.STRANGFORD ndash A single Strangford Lough management committee is to be launched in the spring by the Environment Department.It will consist of about  representatives of lough users, the community around the lough and those with specialist knowledge of the area.This weekrsquos announcement reflects some of the views expressed by the Strangford Lough Nature Conservation Association the body which was set up a few years ago in protest against restrictive DoE proposals.The new body will have the development of management proposals for the lough area as its main task. It will be consulted on any designations or proposals by government or local government relating to the area, including the marine nature reserve..prettyPhoto

title: Gibney’s Hoops double
story: IT was a case of what could have been for Killough, as Celtic Bhoys capitalised on opportunities to stay in the race for the title on Saturday.From the refereersquos first whistle it was a heated event at Ballyhornan with both sides looking to grab possession.The advantage of the wind was with Celtic Bhoys in the first half, and it was a minor error by Killough goalkeeper, James Crangle, in the fourth minute that gted Jay Gibney his first goal of the game.Cranglersquos kick out went direct to the striker and Gibney made no mistake with his finish.The Killough players looked more driven by this and showed great character supporting their goalkeeper to get his head back into the game. Connor Kelly had a chance for the visitors, but Celtic Bhoysrsquo goalkeeper, Nathan Curran, was on form and saved.It was a balanced game as both sides had their chances with Killoughrsquos Kevin Groves coming close in the th minute and Celtic Bhoysrsquo Jordan McCoubrey pushing forwarding search of an opportunity in front of the net.Killoughrsquos Gareth George had to be subbed due to an injury on his ankle and Declan Looney came on in the rd minute of the game. Jack McLaughlin had a one on one chance facing Curran, but the ball went straight at the lsquokeeper before it was cleared.The visitors were keeping up the pressure to level the score, with a surging run up the left wing from Looney, who passed across to find Connor Kelly, but again Nathan Curran saved.The second goal of the game came from a similar scenario to the first ndash a lacklustre kick out that found the feet of Jay Gibney again and Celtic Bhoys went two up going into half-time.Two errors by Killoughrsquos goalkeeper saw the hosts leading at half-time and all of the play was going down the right side of the field.Killough signalled their intentions that the game was not over, as Declan Looney looped the ball into the danger zone, and Nathan Curran somehow got his hand to it to push over the bar.Jay Gibney was set for his hat-trick in the th minute when the Killough custodian came out to stop him in his tracks. Gibney managed to manoeuvre round him, but the ball was cleared by Sean Burns. Celtic Bhoys had another chance to go three up, as three of their players from a free-kick stood looking at one another and the chance went a miss.Killoughrsquos Declan Burns played a great ball from the middle of the field to Declan Looney, who found team-mate Daniel Taggart. The striker saw his shot saved, but the rebound fell to Kevin Groves, who finished to bring his side back into the game with  minutes to go.Celtic Bhoys made a couple of substitutes in the next ten minutes, with Sean McMahon going up front and Sean Ferris ping back into midfield.As the clock ticked to the th minute, Killoughrsquos McLaughlin fired in a free-kick to the head of Eamon Gargan.However, man of the match Nathan Curran pushed the ball at full stretch over the bar.In the final five minutes of play it was all attack by Killough. Kevin Groves had a chance which was denied with Declan Looney quickly following up, although there was no way to find the leveller. It was in the last minute that the Killough goalkeeper made a clearance mistake that saw Shaun Megahey score to break Killough hearts.Celtic Bhoys will be very happy with the win, while Killough will count their missed chances. Nathan Curran made the dference in a tight game, and Killoughrsquos young Crangle will have learnt a lot from the contest for the remaining matches of the season.Celtic Bhoys: N Curran, S Megahey, R Quinn, R Fitzpatrick, M Rice, C Doherty, B Tracey, P Casey, J Gibney, J McCoubrey, C Kerr.Subs: E Kelly for P Casey, S McMahon for J McCoubrey, S Ferris for Conaill Kerr.Killough FC: J Crangle, R Burns, E Gargan, C Burns, S Og Burns, D Burns, C Kelly, G George, D Taggart, K Groves, J McLaughlin.Subs: D Looney for G George, K Tierney, C Doyle..prettyPhoto

title: It’s like a little  safe haven here%2C somewhere you can come and cry and not get judged
story: TEARS still spring easily to the eyes of Dympna Kerr, the sister of Columba McVeigh, one of the lsquoDisappearedrsquo victims.Once she begins to talk about her  year-old brother, whose body has never been recovered after he was abducted and murdered by the IRA in , after nearly  years of dealing with his loss the pain remains.Last weekend, the Donaghmore woman left her home in St Helenrsquos in Merseyside to travel to a welcoming building in the coastal village of Killough.At the newly named Wave By The Sea centre in Castle Street, Dympna spent precious time speaking with longstanding friends who are also relatives of the Disappeared. The main dference is that they have been fortunate to locate the bodies of their loved one. Several searches have yet toher brotherrsquos remains to the family but they remain hopeful.ldquoItrsquos like a little safe haven here, somewhere you can come and cry and not get judged. The people you are crying to know why you are crying as they understand, explained Dympna about her lasting need to connect with people with shared experience.ldquoGoing to the Wave house in Belfast is like going home. Itrsquos like getting a hug as soon as you go across the door. And itrsquos the same here as Irsquove already been several times.The help and support of the iniduals who make up the Wave Trauma Centre quietly helps thousands of people like Dympna who have been bereaved, injured and or traumatised by the decades of conflict in Northern Ireland.The building has been provided by the local trustees of The Kinder Project, a charitable Dutch organisation that began its association with Northern Ireland in the s for the education and social welfare of disadvantaged children and young adults.The hostel now provides residential breaks for a maximum of  people, providing rooms for families and iniduals, who use the time to break away from their lives still traumatised and dealing with the physical and emotional aftermath.Counselling and complimentary therapy sessions are offered and other courses are provided by Wave to help those who come, many of whom have never sought help before.Itrsquos the sixth centre around the province that Wave has established, along with r satellite projects, with support funding from the Victims and Support Service, NI Executive, Special EU Programmes Body and charitable donations.One of the Troubles survivors who wished the service had been available locally for him and his family is Killough man Peter Heathwood.Peter knows the benefit of support from Wave. In September  he was left paralysed after a Loyalist gun attack in his Belfast home as he played with his youngest daughter in his living room mdash bullets missing the baby by inches.His attack was witnessed by his late we and two eldest children. His father Hubert died from a heart attack at the scene when he saw his apparently dead son.As a member of the Wave Injured Group, he has campaigned for years for a state pension for people left physically or psychologically injured from the conflict.He has yet to receive his pension, even though he applied for it last autumn.ldquoI had to travel to Belfast night and day and only discovered Wave when I went on to the Victimsrsquo Forum years after my shooting, said Peter.ldquoMy we died at  with a diagnosis of PTSD and suffered with flashbacks. If I had found Wave earlier, I reckon it could have saved her as she could have met other women and shared stories and experiences.ldquoWhen I was shot, I passed out but she saw me lying there with blood pumping out of me, children screaming and my father dying. She could never deal with the fact that she opened the door to the gunmen. But I told her thatshe hadnrsquot have shouted a warning to me, I would have been dead as I was able to get up and slam the door.ldquoEven in this village, there are people who moved from Belfast and a lot of them lost relatives in the Troubles, uncles, fathers, grandfathers and many of them never speak about it. I didnrsquot really talk about it to my own children as you didnrsquot want them to be filled with hate.Peter said that even on holiday when people asked what happened to him, he would say he was injured skiing in the French Alps, a more sanitised version of his attack mdash purportedly in mistake for another man mdash as he enjoyed an evening at home with his family.ldquoWave is a fantastic organisation. We are completely cross-community. Everyone has been hurt by all groups and thatrsquos the great strength of it, said Peter.ldquoI would really encourage anyone who has affected by the Troubles and has never sought help to come along to Wave. Itrsquos never too late to talk.Waversquos chief executive officer, Sandra Peake, says that the new centre will help  people in the immediate area and around  from the district, in addition to providing weekend residential breaks from families across Northern Ireland, Britain and the Irish Republic.ldquoThis wouldnrsquot have been possible without the generosity of the Kinder Project, explained Sandra, who said that the building has been fitted out to reflect a more comfortable family style accommodation.ldquoWe had initially done some work in Downpatrick about  years ago to see what we could have provided but have always been keen to provide a local base, which Kinder has now provided to us.ldquoThe welcome from the people and the shopkeepers of Killough has been brilliant. They seem to know why our visitors are staying here and give them a respectful place and go beyond and above to help them.ldquoSome of the families have enjoyed paddle boarding lessons on the water with children experiencing this type of activity for the first time. One grandmother got to sleep in a bed for the first time in years as she normally sleeps on the couch to let her grandchildren have the bed.Wave By The Sea is much more than a weekend or holiday break.ldquoWe aim to provide a holistic service here for people. It will start with an outreach case worker working with you to establish what your needs are and then that moves us into seeing what we can provide, whether its counselling, physiotherapy, group support and so on, Sandra continued.ldquoSeventy per cent of Waversquos work is service provision, the remainder is trauma education. We have a whole range of short trauma courses now and we hope to run courses her.ldquoThey deal with how trauma affects families, recognising the impact of trauma and how to build resilience, the intergenerational impact and issues such as trauma addiction as we would see people with issues. We also provide trauma education for healthcare professionals and student doctors, nurses, and social workers.She predicts an increase of demand for services as new referrals increased last year in part due to interest in the Injured Pension scheme and the proposed Legacy proposals.ldquoThe majority of people coming to us now have never gone anyway for help. But dferent things are stirring memories. We hope to provide counselling and complementary therapy sessions in Newcastle within a few months.Sandra is recruiting a Health and Wellbeing caseworker who would be based in Killough but would also work in the Newcastle area and stressed that all services were provided on a confidential basis.One of the trustees of the Kinder Project, local man Dr Finbar McCormick, is delighted that the building is being used by Wave.ldquoKinder was a Dutch charity that took children from troubled areas to Holland in the s and then established a local centre in Killough for breaks, he explained. ldquoChildren from other troubled spots like Kosovo and the Balkans were also taken for holidays here over the years.ldquoWith the peace process, the need for the Kinder House just fell away and we were looking for another group to pass it onto so that they could make good use of it.ldquoI happened to meet Peter, who I know, one day while out for a walk and I said to him that we really needed to find another group to use the hostel. Peter said that he would mention it to Wave and that was about  months and Wave has been using it for the last six months.ldquoIt was an excellent choice for us as we really wanted to keep the place going and Wave will continue the same aims that Kinder had.To apply for the caseworker position or to access services, visit Wave www.wavetraumacentre.org.uk or ring   ..prettyPhoto

title: Kilcoo set for Croker
story: KILCOO are officially back to back All-Ireland Senior Club Championship finalists after a gruelling clash with Cork side, St Finbarrrsquos, was dramatically settled in extra-time on Saturday.In a thoroughly entertaining contest that had twist after twist, Mickey Moranrsquos men eventually booked their place to contend for the Andy Merrigan Cupwhich has agonisingly eluded the local outfit over the last few years.With the headlines seemingly written in the dying seconds of regulation time, Kilcoorsquos Paul Devlin steadied his frame to send the deciding free between the posts.However, a moment of off-the-ball madness from team-mate Aidan Branagan resulted in a sending off and a further  minutes of added drama.Despite this, the Magpies showed their stamina and experience within this competition and managed to finish comfortably five points adrt from their opponents.The scene was set at a mild Portlaoise venue as sunshine attempted to split through the clouds and past the overshadowing OrsquoMoore Park spectator stands where the Ulster and Munster champions prepared to lock horns.Although the local side won referee Brendan Cawleyrsquos throw-in, it would be The Barrrsquos who would open the scoring from a Cillian Myers-Murray effort.Kilcoo replied rapidly through the reliable Ryan Johnston, who navigated his way past the opposing defence to curl one over the bar to level the tie.The Magpies would soon be soaring when they immediately turned over possession and saw an opportunity for the first goal of the match.Jerome Johnston cleverly spotted his brother, Ryan, and played a quick hand pass into his path where he made no mistake in burying his effort into the top left corner of the net beyond the ing Barrrsquosrsquo custodian, John Kerins.Despite this early blow, the Cork-based outfit remained determined and went on the offensive.Eoin McGreevy took the mark and kicked over before receiving a yellow card for a high tackle on Ryan Johnston.Kilcoorsquos Conor Laverty was rewarded for his tireless work ethic in the form of winning a free, although team-mate Paul Devlin saw his effort uncharacteristically drt wide from what was a very straightforward chance.Colin Lyons was the latest to enter Cawleyrsquos book with  minutes played following a late tackle on Niall Branagan that left the Kilcoo number two worse for wear.Steven Sherlock successfully converted his first of ten frees for The Barrrsquos to bring his side to within a point, but Laverty answered this with a score from play to widen the winning margin once more.St Finbarrrsquos were notably the physically bigger side and it was clear they were initiating a rougher style of play.This was evident after Sherlock again split the posts from a free, when Kilcoorsquos Ceilum Doherty looked to reply and instead was clattered by defender Sam Ryan.This time, Devlin made no mistake with his attempt which would have helped settle his nerves from his earlier miss.Sherlock pointed his third free of the match in retaliation in what was now a tit for tat contest.However, The Barrrsquos managed to swing the tie hugely in their favour when Kilcoorsquos Daryl Branagan forfeited possession close to his goal and the onrushing Eoin Comyns took full advantage.The Barrrsquos number nine quickly passed to team-mate Sherlock, who set up McGreevy for their sidersquos first goal of the match.Despite the efforts of Kilcoo lsquokeeper Niall Kane, McGreevy managed to creep his shot round the custodian to fire his team into the lead minutes before half-time.With seconds to the interval, Denis OrsquoBrien received a yellow to join the growing list of his St Finbarrrsquos team-mates to go into the refereersquos book.As the whistle sounded, both sides engaged in some roughhousing as tensions reached fever pitch.Half time: St Finbarrrsquos - Kilcoo -.The Barrrsquos won the second half throw-in and went on the attack through a surging Sherlock run that resulted in a free - which he duly converted.This sprung The Magpies into action with rising star Shealan Johnston running past three defenders before kicking over the bar for a magnicent solo point. Team-mate Devlin then converted a free to pile on the pressure.Opposing number eights, Dylan Ward and Ian Maguire, were having a notable midfield battle which drew attention fromboth sets of supporters on numerous occasions but often it was the Kilcoo man coming out on top.lsquoKeeper Kane kicked an effort off the ground and over the bar on the rd minute before Eugene Branagan scored a point from play to give The Magpies the lead.As was the theme of the contest, Sherlock knocked over a brace of frees for the Munster champions and the score line swayed once more.Daryl Branagan curled two points from play over the bar before Ryan McEvoy was shown the yellow card for a foul on the opposition. Sherlock duly converted the resulting free and now the game was in its last ten minutes of regulation time.Ward received a yellow card for more off the ball antics with Maguire but Kilcoo kept on scoring through the left boot of Devlin, who split the posts after receiving a neat pass from Daryl Branagan.As the officials indicated four additional minutes, The Magpies held a narrow one point lead with the scores reading - to -.On the rd minute, The Barrrsquos were afforded the chance to draw level from a long ranged free which Sherlock made no mistake in doing.With seemingly one lastthrow of the dice, Kilcoo launched the ball forward to the experienced Devlin, who drew the foul as he attempted to pick up the pass.With what everyone thought was the final kick of the game, Devlin prepared to knock over his free and send his side through to a second successive All-Ireland final.However, there would be one last twist before the whistle.To everyone in attendance and those watching at homersquos disbelief, Kilcoo joint-captain Aidan Branagan, who was only on the pitch for a matter of minutes, needlessly collided with Barrrsquos replacement Adam Lyne off-the-ball.After brief deliberation, referee Cawley gave Branagan his marching orders in the form of a red card and reversed his decision from a free to a throw ball.The full-time whistle sounded seconds later and the game headed to extra-time.Despite the high drama, Kilcoo would not be denied and dominated the following duration of the contest.Custodian Kane was first to kick over, before Anthony Morgan doubled the deficit. Sherlock pulled one back for The Barrrsquos from a free but Micheal Rooney quickly cancelled this out at the other end.Devlin extended the lead to three and yet again Sherlock proved reliable for The Barrrsquos through a converted free.However, Kilcoo clearly had prepared for these extraminutes and scoring opportunities looked to be seldom for their opposition, although Colm Barrett did split the posts after Devlin curled over another point.lsquoKeeper Kane saw his rsquo sail over the bar to restore a two point lead and from here St Finbarrrsquos ran out of gas.Jamie Burns saw red for the Cork side after punching out at Doherty, and Kilcoo were now afforded the extra space to stamp their authority in the closing minutes.Despite Ward picking up a late black card, a brace of Doherty points rounded off the scoring as the match finally reached its climax at - to -.After the contest, Kilcoo lsquokeeper Niall Kane spoke about his sidersquos performance and reaching yet another All-Ireland final.ldquoWe knew it was going to be tough when you get to the last four in Ireland, he said.ldquoYes everybody was saying Kilcoo were going to be red hot favourites, but deep down we knew St Finbarrrsquos are no walkover and they proved that.ldquoItrsquos only a semi-final, therersquos nothing won yet so we are back at it in the morning, get our recovery and training Monday night.St Finbarrrsquos: J Kerins S Ryan, J Burns, C Scully C Lyons, B Hennessy, A OrsquoConnor I Maguire, Eoin Comyms D OrsquoBrien, S Sherlock , B Hayes C Myers-Murray , E McGreevy , C McCrickard.Subs: E Dennehy for C Myers-Murray, C Barrettfor D OrsquoBrien, M Shields for E McGreevy, A Lyne for C McCrickard.Kilcoo: N KaneN Branagan, R McEvoy, Aaron BranaganM Rooney, D Branagan , E BranaganD Ward, Aaron Morgan C Doherty , J Johnston, S JohnstonC Laverty, R Johnston , P Devlin .Subs: Anthony Morganfor Laverty, Aidan Branagan for Aaron Morgan, C Laverty for Aidan Branagan, T Fettes for R Johnston, J Clarke for M Rooney.Referee: Brendan Cawley ..prettyPhoto

title: Marc (18) remembered as ‘an unassuming and polite young man’
story: THE funeral of a teenager who died in a road accident near Castlewellan at the weekend takes place later today.Marc Quinn died after being struck by a car on the Newcastle Road in the early hours of Sunday morning.It is believed that Marc, who celebrated his th birthday last Wednesday, was walking home when the accident occurred shortly before .am.He was treated at the scene before being taken to hospital, but sadly died a short time later.Police are appealing to anyone who witnessed the incident to contact them.The funeral cortege will leave Marcrsquos home in Annsborough today at .pm for Requiem Mass in St Malachyrsquos Church in Castlewellan at pm, to be followed by interment at St Maryrsquos Cemetery, Aughlisnafin.Marc was a talented Gaelic footballer who was a senior player for Aughlisnafin GAC.His mother, Jenny, is the club secretary, and his father, Garry, is a former player. His brothers, Ruairi and Ryan, both play for the club.In a statement on social media, the club said: ldquoMarc was an extremely talented and committed footballer for Aughlisnafin GAC from a five year-old playing at every grade and was looking forward to making his senior debut this season.ldquoMarc won U-. and U- championship medals and captained the U- East Down league winning side.ldquoHe has also represented his school team St Malachyrsquos HS with distinction and was part of the Down GAA U- and U- development squads.ldquoHe also enjoyed his time with Baile an Locha minors and also a time with our friends and neighbours Liatroim Fontenoys to play U- football in his own grade.ldquoHe made many friends wherever he played. He will be sorely missed by all his club mates and friends both in and out of the club. ldquoSuch an unassuming and polite young man, who was extremely well thought of both within our club and wherever he went.ldquoWords cannot begin to convey the heartbreak we feel for his beloved parents Garry and Jenny, for his brothers Ruairi and Ryan, and the extended Quinn Grant family circle and friends. They are all in our thoughts and prayers at this dficult time.ldquoOn behalf of the Quinn Grant family we thank all those clubs and iniduals who sent messages of support. They are a measure of comfort to the family at a very dficult time for them.ldquoAs a mark of respect all club activities are cancelled until after the funeral.Tributes have been paid by a number of other local GAA clubs.St Johnrsquos GAC said on Facebook: ldquoMarc was very close to our hearts here at St Johns GAC as he was a member of our Ballylough amalgamation team. He will be fondly remembered by his team mates and coaches here at the club.ldquoWe would like to send our deepest and most sincere sympathies to the Quinn family and everyone at Aughlisnafin GAC.Kilcoo GAC, who won an All-Ireland senior club semi-final on Saturday, said on Facebook: ldquoIt is with the deepest regret we write this message today after our famous victory yesterday.ldquoMarc Quinn, an  year-old boy and a member of the Aughlisnafin GAC club was tragically killed last night. Marc is a nephew of Mary McEvoy, we of Barry.ldquoEoghan Rua Cill Chua sends our deepest and most sincere sympathies to the Quinn McEvoy families and everyone at Aughlisnafin GAC.Castlewellan GAC said: ldquoLike everyone in our community and the surrounding area, we are shocked and saddened by the sudden death of  year-old Marc Quinn as a result of a road accident in the early hours of last Sunday morning.The executive committee and members of CLG Naomh Maolmhaodhoacuteg, Caisleaacuten Uidhiliacuten, wish to extend our deepest sympathies to his mother and father, Jenny and Gary, his brothers, Ruairi and Ryan, and the entire Quinn family circle at this most dficult of times.Among the other local GAA clubs to offer condolences are Liatroim, Drumaness, Saul, Ardglass, Bright and the RGU club in Downpatrick.A number of politicians have expressed their condolences to Mr Quinnrsquos family.Local SDLP councillor Hugh Gallagher said the family were devastated and described Mr Quinn as a ldquogentleman who everyone in the area knew.ldquoOur thoughts and prayers are with the family, he said. ldquoHe was a gentleman and a quiet young fella.ldquoThe traumatic aspect of it as well is the young man who lost his le is a son and a brother.ldquoItrsquos a very sad day for the whole community. It is a very close-knit community and they will rally round and support the family.SDLP MLA Colin McGrath said it was never easy to lose a loved one, especially in ldquosuch dficult circumstances and such a young age.UUP councillor Alan Lewis thanked the emergency services and said the tragedy was another reminder that Northern Irelandrsquos roads are an ldquoever present danger.Alliance councillor Andy McMurray said it was ldquoheart-breaking and added that the local GAA community had suffered a huge loss.The PSNIrsquos Collision Investigation Unit are appealing for anyone who witnessed the incident, or who may have dash-cam footage, to contact them on  quoting reference  of   ..prettyPhoto

title: Matthew in step to dance his way into next round
story: LOVE Islander Matthew MacNabb trotted into the next round of RTErsquos Dancing With The Stars with a pacy dance number.The Downpatrick man and his professional partner Laura Nolan were the first pair to dance on Sundayrsquos programme with an impressive foxtrot.Dancing to You Got A Friend in Me from Toy Story, the  year-old played the role of Woody, the lead character from one of his favourite movies.The performance won praise and encouragement from the judges, earning Matthew his highest score to date and out of the dance off.To top off the night, Matthew was supported by his parents, Vincent and Margaret MacNabb, his brother Conaill and sister-in-law as well as aunts and uncles who travelled down to Dublin for the show.Instead of being overawed by dancing first, the fitness fanatic and marketing consultant told the Recorder that it helped him rise to the occasion.He said: ldquoI was absolutely thrilled to open the show on its most famous week, Movie Week. It was a big honour. Especially to play a character in one of my favourite movies of all time.ldquoI was excited but also nervous because I wanted to do the character justice. I had danced so well all last week that I would have been angry at myself for not nailing it.ldquoI do have to say that the most important feedback for me is the local people supporting me, voting for me and driving me to work harder every day. So thank you to all of you.The judges were suitably impressed, awarding him  votes.Loraine Barry told Matthew: ldquoYou definitely have a friend in me tonight, and that is because Irsquom impressed.Arthur Gourounlian said: ldquoYou brought le to this dance tonight, while Brian Redmond added: ldquoYour dancing for the last few weeks has been pretty wooden, here you are dressed as Woody, finally moving with a bit of fluidity.Matthew said that he really valued the feedback after a few hesitant performances.ldquoThe relief I felt was unreal. I worked so hard for weeks on end, every single day, doing - hours per day and to get positive feedback and appreciation for my hard work is such a nice feeling, he said.He has a newfound respect for the discipline and fitness that is required of professional dancers.ldquoWhen I signed up to Dancing With The Stars, I had no idea how mentally and physically draining it would be, he explained.ldquoThis process has shown me how talented and hard working professional dancers are. They work all day every day and I mean every single day.ldquoIrsquom used to pushing my body physically from playing Gaelic for RGU and hurling for Liatroim as well as lting the occasional weight but this is a new form of mental stamina. Itrsquos an unreal learning experience.Comedian Neil Delamare was the second celebrity dancer voted off, having scored  for his cha-cha-cha.Matthew will be ing to a Latin dance for next weekrsquos show and is promising to use his strength to do some lts with Laura.He was approached to take part on the show following his stint in the popular ITV dating show, Love Island, last summer.Check out Matthewrsquos progress on Dancing With The Stars this Sunday, at .pm on RTEacute One..prettyPhoto

title: Minister asked to assist soccer club secure pitch
story: STORMONT Education Minister Michelle McIlveen has been asked to play a key role in a bid by Ballynahinch Olympic Football Club to secure the use of a school pitch in the town for home games.Discussions to allow the soccer club to use a pitch at The High School Ballynahinch on the Belfast Road started several years ago with progress on drawing up a partnership arrangement to allow the proposal to come to fruition disrupted by the coronavirus pandemic.Last Friday, Ms McIlveen met with the school principal, Mr Paul Marks, and representatives from the football club to learn more about the proposal during a visit to the town.Joining them were representatives from the schoolrsquos Board of Governors, Strangford MP Jim Shannon and local councillors Billy Walker, Terry Andrews and Cathy Mason.Mr Shannon said Ballynahinch was known for its strong community relations and also those between schools and sports clubs.He saidBallynahinch Olympic could secure permission to use the high schoolrsquos sports pitches for its home games, it would further strengthen relations in the town.ldquoI hope that the Education Authority will be able to facilitate the football clubrsquos request to use the school pitch and the commitment by the Education Minister towards this end is welcome, Mr Shannon continued.ldquoIt is crucial that Ballynahinch Olympic has a permanent home and that the high school has better sporting opportunities.Mr Shannon described last Fridayrsquos meeting with Ms McIlveen as a ldquostep in the right direction and looked forward to further discussions.Cllr Walker said Ms McIlveen was asked to visit last week and meet with Ballynahinch Olympic officials after he and Cllr Andrews were contacted by Cllr Mason about the pitch sharing proposal which had been around for several years.He said that before Christmas he and Cllr Andrews met with club officials and reaffirmed their support for what he described as a cross-community proposal.ldquoLast weekrsquos meeting between all the ious parties was lsquopositive and productiversquo and I and others recognise that what is being proposed is good for Ballynahinch, Cllr Walker continued.ldquoWhat is being suggested makes sense and I hope that the Education Authority and Department of Education will weigh in with their support. It will be good for Ballynahinch Olympic to play their home games in their own town which they cannot do at present.Cllr Walker said following last weekrsquos meeting, Ms McIlveen will now discuss the issue with her officials and he is hoping for a positive outcome.He added: ldquoThe proposal by Ballynahinch Olympic to use the school can only be good for the town and is an example of the good community relations that exist..prettyPhoto

title: Minister hears about  blue carbon habitat
story: STORMONT Environment Minister Edwin Poots was a recent visitor to Castle Espie Wetland Centre, near Comber, recently.The main purpose of the visit to the centre was to highlight ongoing evidence gathering and efforts to protect and enhance high nature value blue carbon habitats.Mr Poots described blue carbon habitats as a ldquopowerful and signicant natural resource to help in the fight against climate change.He explained the habitats support wider bioersity, protect against coastal erosion and flooding, are nursery grounds for commercially important fish species, and have societal wellbeing benefits.Mr Poots said it was ldquogreat to see for himself how important saltmarsh blue carbon habitats are during his visit when he met with staff from Wildfowl and Wetlands Trustmdash who manage the site at Castle Espie mdash DAERA staff and partners from Ulster Wildle.ldquoOver the past  years, under the careful and patient management of WWT staff, new saltmarsh habitat has been created at Castle Espie, said Mr Poots.ldquoThis habitat plays a vital role in not just in carbon capture and storage, but also the wider nature and social benefits such as providing coastal defence, foraging and breeding grounds for wintering birds, and a key tourist facility on a beautul stretch of our coastline.Mr Poots added: ldquoItrsquos important that policies and decisions are based on sound evidence and I am delighted that my Department has been able to fund key blue carbon research in Northern Ireland.ldquoMy officials have also been working with other UK administrations and through the British-Irish Council, to share learning on blue carbon habitats, and this knowledge transfer is proving very beneficial.Castle Espie director Paul Stewart was delighted with the ministerrsquos visit to view the conservation work carried out and the recognition of the benefit to both people and planet of wetland habitats.ldquoThe wetland centre provides the public with a window on Strangford Lough, one of Northern Irelandrsquos most beautul natural assets and with the worlds wetlands storing more carbon than the worldrsquos forests combined that beauty is more than skin deep, he continued.ldquoWe look forward to working in partnership with DAERA and our peer conservation charities on the Blue Carbon Action Plan for Northern Ireland and highlighting the important role habitats such as can be found at Castle Espie play in carbon sequestration and addressing the bioersity crisis.The Ulster Wildlersquos director of nature, climate and environment, Dr Annika Clements, said the role of woodlands and peatlands in carbon sequestration has been well known for some time, but said marine equivalents have often been overlooked, despite the oceans absorbing nearly a third of CO emissions that human activity generates each year.ldquoUlster Wildlersquos blue carbon projects are the first step in Northern Ireland recognising the potential of coastal blue carbon habitats such as saltmarsh, seagrass and shellfish to lock away carbon, particularly within our Marine Protected Area network, but only when they are well managed and healthy, she said.ldquoIntegrating blue carbon protection and recovery into climate change mitigation and adaptation, as part of a wider approach to meet net zero targets is a win-win for tackling both the climate and bioersity crises, helping to bring our precious seas back to le..prettyPhoto

title: Murlough AC raise funds for foodbank
story: MURLOUGH AC held their annual k Christmas fun run on Sunday, December .Last year the nominated charity was the Pantry Foodbank in Newcastle.Mrs Clausand Mr Clausprovided the appropriate festive attire for the MAC Juniors and other children of MAC members.Everyone made a brilliant effort to dress up in festive gear. Declan provided the warm-up and off we all went.A few huffs and puffs on the way round with a few little tired legs, but we all arrived back in one piece and were treated to sweets, mince pies and lots of other goodies.The club also presented members with their annual Christmas pressie mdash a lovely long sleeve training top, brilliant for those winter nights in Newcastle.A fantastic sum of pound was raised for the Pantry Foodbank and Margaret Rowntree presented the cheque to Manus OrsquoBaoill.Murlough AC would like to thank the committee members who arrived early that morning to set everything up and made the morning special for the kids.The committee would like to thank those who attended and gave so generously, and also to those that could not make it but who also donated which raised a fantastic amount of money for the foodbank..prettyPhoto

title: Newry Museum curator also takes over reins at  Down County Museum
story: NEWRY, Mourne and Down Council has appointed a new curator for Down County Museum.The appointment of Noreen Cunningham to take over at the helm of the Downpatrick complex comes after stinging criticism of the local authorityrsquos decision to base her in Newry.Confirmation of Ms Cunninghamrsquos appointment came yesterday in a press release issued by the local council describing her as a ldquoseasoned professional with over  years of curatorial experience.Prior to working in the museum sector, she worked for several years as an archaeologist on excavations throughout Ireland, as well as extensive field surveys of hundreds of archaeological sites within Northern Ireland, primarily in Co Down and Derry.Ms Cunningham has a degree in Archaeology and Social Anthropology from Queenrsquos University and an MSc in Cultural Management from the University of Ulster.From  to  she held a Research Fellowship at the Institute of Irish Studies at Queenrsquos University.Between  and  she was seconded to the Northern Ireland Museums Council as assistant director and was involved in a wide range of work, including providing advice to the local museum sector, assessing grant-applications to the Museum Councilrsquos funding streams as well as being involved in several research projects on ious aspects of the museum sector in Northern Ireland.Council chairwoman Cathy Mason said Ms Cunninghamrsquos appointment was an extension of her current role as curator of Newry and Mourne Museum.ldquoNoreen has a wealth of experience and an ambition to drive forward the growth of the councilrsquos museumsrsquo service in Newry and Downpatrick over the coming years, she said.ldquoThe Council is fully committed to the continuous improvement and development of our two museums. Through the work of dedicated museum officers, including our curator, the Down County and Newry and Mourne museums both provide a high quality visitor experience.ldquoThey receive very positive reviews from visitors, offer excellent education programmes for local school groups and have a strong connection to our local communities.Cllr Mason said she welcomed Ms Cunninghamrsquos appointment and the important work of the museums in contributing to the districtrsquos culture and heritage.The new curator in charge at the Downpatrick museum has been involved in the production of over  publications and has written extensively on erse aspects of heritage ranging from museum topics, local history and archaeology.She has served on a number of organisations and bodies. From -, she was chairperson of Northern Ireland Regional Curators Group and a board member of the Northern Ireland Museums Council.Ms Cunningham is also currently Museum Mentor for Armagh Robinson Library and as curator of Newry and Mourne Museum, has been involved in the restoration of Bagenalrsquos Castle, home of Newry and Mourne Museum, in .From - she planned and delivered a complete revamp of its museum galleries and also delivered two annual temporary exhibitions with accompanying booklets, as well as a number of travelling exhibitions such as the  Famine Commemoration exhibition and a  exhibition.Last month, the council was accused of ldquodowngrading the status of Down County Museum with a former senior staff member claiming that the museumrsquos role was being reduced to that of a visitor centre because of staff cuts.There has also been criticism of the decision to have one curator in charge of Down County Museum and Newry and Mourne Museum, with opponents of the move insisting that a full-time curator was needed in Downpatrick to ensure ldquoprofessional standards are maintained..prettyPhoto

title: Plant a tree plan branching out across province
story: ARDS and North Down Council has weighed in with its support for a province-wide initiative to plant a tree for every school pupil as part of the global drive to tackle the climate emergency.Last year, councillors in Newry, Mourne and Down highlighted the need to raise awareness about the climate crisis when they were addressed by students from Down High Schoolrsquos Eco Committee.In addition to being asked to raise awareness about the global issue, the local authority also committed to doing what it can to improve wildle habitat and backed a proposal to organise a community fun day involving schools and the community to plant trees.The Down High students were given an opportunity to address Newry, Mourne and Down councillors after winning a lsquoDragonrsquos Denrsquo style event as part of Local Democracy Week, with councillors affirming their understanding that itrsquos their generationrsquos duty to protect the environment.In addition, the students highlighted concern about increasing levels of CO emissions and the low density of woodland, accepting an amendment to their motion from Rowallane councillor Billy Walker who called for a province-wide initiative to provide every school pupil with a tree they could plant.Following its meeting with the students last year, Newry, Mourne and Down Council agreed to write to the provincersquos  other local authorities and the Assembly to seek their support for the studentsrsquo proposal.Ards and North Down Council is the latest local authority to back the Down High studentsrsquo campaign following a proposal by Cllr Philip Smith.He said he was delighted to propose that the organisation support Down Highrsquos campaign to increase tree planting across Northern Ireland.Cllr Smith said that following his proposal, Ards and North Down Council will now write to Stormont agriculture minister, Edwin Poots, asking him to commit to providing a tree for every school pupil in Northern Ireland and asked for this to happen every year moving forward.He also revealed that Ards and North Down Council has embarked on a major tree planting strategy of its own and that over the next decade will plant , trees, one for every person in the Borough.ldquoItrsquos critically important that we increase our tree cover as trees act as carbon sinks to absorb carbon dioxide, the main greenhouse gas and produce oxygen, continued Cllr Smith.ldquoTrees also reduce the effects of flooding, increase bioersity and even reduce noise levels by acting as a sound barrier.But Cllr Smith said that according to the Woodland Trust, only % of the land in Northern Ireland is covered by trees, comparing badly with the rest of the UK which has % tree cover and well behind the European average of %.He added: ldquoIt is widely accepted that we are in a climate emergency and it is our younger generations who will inherit its out-workings and it is encouraging to see them being so proactive to help improve the situation.ldquoThat is why I fully support this great initiative by the pupils at Down High and I hope Minister Poots will deliver for them..prettyPhoto

title: Portaferry hold on for first Ulster title
story: PORTAFERRY became the fourth Down team to collect the Ulster Intermediate Club Championship over its  year history as they hung on for a single point victory against holders Eglish in Tullylish on Saturday.They follow on from Liatroim Fontenoys , Clonduffand Ballycran .Indeed Liatroimrsquos first two and Clonduffrsquos middle successes were converted into All-Ireland titles and that will be the next goal in a dream season for Portaferry, who only won their first ever Down title back in November. Eglish had the much better start and led by - to - at the first water-break.However, it was Portaferryrsquos spurt during the second quarter that put them in command of the game and they were able to maintain that gap throughout the second half and into the final few minutes before Eglish closed it to a single point.With two quality free-takers on show and a referee who awarded plenty of frees, it was always going to come down to small margins.Niamh Mallon missed little for the winners while two late Ciara Donnelly effortsboth pulled to the left of the posts in a dficult breeze. If either had gone over we were set for another  minutes of intense action. Donnelly was on target early in the game and shot four points in the opening quarter.However, the key score was a free from her sister Leanne that was touched to the net by Niamh McNulty for the first goal that Portaferry had conceded in five games.Despite this, the first-time Down champions knuckled down and quickly hauled in the four pointsrsquo lead Eglish took to the water-break.Niamh Mallon added her fourth free before Frances Toner was taken down in the th minute by Laura Mason for a penalty. Julie Lagan brilliantly saved Mallonrsquos shot, but it wasnrsquot fully cleared and Mallon won herself a free that she converted.Lagan also saved another pile-driver from Mallon a few minutes later before an injury time goal from Mia Fitzsimons sent the Down side in with a lead of - to -.With the breeze behind them, Eglish set about eating into the lead. Donnelly pointed a couple of frees during the third quarter. However the Portaferry defence, with extra cover coming from Saoirse Sands and Mia Fitzsimons, held firm while Mallon added two pointsinside  seconds around the  minute mark.It was - to - at the second water-break and Mallon pointed a free on the resumption of play. Portaferry looked to be on their way to the winners enclosure.However, a penalty awarded for a trip on Niamh McNulty was converted by Donnelly in the nd minute and suddenly it was game on again.Donnelly pointed a free to close the gap to two points a minute later before a long free from Mallon fell for Saoirse Sands to point in the th minute. There was still time for Eglish to win four frees, two of which Donnelly managed to convert before time ran out on them and Portaferry took their title.Portaferry: F McGarry, C Coleman , A Mallon, MJ Mageean, C Finnegan, D Coleman, C McKenna, E Gallagher , N Savage, C McConnell, S Sands , E McGrattan, M Fitzsimons , N Mallon , F Toner.Subs: C Coleman for C McConnell , G McGrattan for E McGrattan .Eglish: J Lagan, F Farley, C Muldoon, A Donnelly, L Mason, A Jordan, C Jordan, C Gallagher, C McGready, K Gallagher, L Donnelly , C Goodfellow, S Kelly, C Donnelly , N McNulty .Subs: A Barrett for C Goodfellow , R Fay for F Farley , G Daly for L Mason .Referee: EP Mullan ..prettyPhoto

title: Punters enjoy Tyrella event
story: FOLLOWING an absence of  months the East Downs were once again able to run a point-to-point at the Corbett family estate at Tyrella in decent conditions on Saturday.While the East Down point-to-point was one of the last meetings to take place before the lockdown, it was also the first to be able to welcome back crowds without having to register online in advance for contact tracing.Sadly due to the lack of recent rain, firm going saw a smaller entry of runners than expected.In the Bluegrass ndash Dengie three winners race six faced the starter, Craig Caven, and his new assistant, James Armstrong.Jordan Radclfe setting out to make all in Glebeparkhawk in the New CafeRacing Club colours. The tactic looked like paying off, but at the post So Ladylike, with Caoimhe OrsquoBrien in the saddle, got up to provide the rider with her second success, her first coming on this Alana McGuinness-owned runner back in October. Ballinasilla finished a close third.The winner is trained by Ian Donoghue, a brother of top Northern Ireland jockey Keith, who is no longer with Gordon Elliott.Only six of the  entries took part in the Dennison JCB Maiden Race for five year-old geldings, but the race provided spectators with a close finish.The Aaron Sinnott-ridden Song For My Father, owned and trained in Co Cavan by Shane Donohoe, just passed the judge ahead of Time For A Pint, ridden by Tom Hamilton for Co Carlow trainer Shark Hanlon, with Hapy La Vie back in third ahead of Old Style Humor.It was not long before a stewardsrsquo enquiry was called with the result that the winner was disqualied for failing to draw the correct weight. Time For A Pint was placed first ahead of Hapy La Vie and Old Style Humor .Four set out in the Kingsfield Stud five year-old Mares Maiden Race, but only three remained after the fourth fence, after Paddy Cleary lost his irons and was unseated.This left Born Famous to win from Famous Function and local hope Social Distancing. For trainer Claire OrsquoConnell it was a welcome winner. Paul Bannon was the successful rider.The Cosy Roof Open Race saw the grey Creadan Grae make most of the running but in the end had to be content with second to the ex-English trained Brain Power mdash a rare open horse for Warren Ewing, who is best known for producing top four year-olds.The successful rider was Maghera-based Oran McGill who was replacing his injured younger brother Dara. Warren is part of the well known fish merchant family. Third home was Bajan Excell, ridden by Ben OrsquoBrien.The connections of the runner-up in this race, Broughshane owner Philip McBurney, rider Noel McParlan and trainer Gerry Quinn, also based at Broughshane, had better fortune in the Armstrong Auctions  year-old and Upwards Mares Maiden when Tamlaght Eyes, pulled up in her previous three races, proved to be the smooth winner from the Lee Shawagen-ridden Any Time with Castle Arms Casa a very close third.The final race on the card was the G Curran  Co Ltd Maiden Race for  year-old and Upwards Geldings. Ask Charlie was the easy winner from Kilmoganny, ridden by Tiernan Power-Roche, and Robbie Armstrongrsquos ex-English trained Carolersquos Templer, ridden by Deckie Lavery.Good to see the long established Denis Reddan colours in the winning enclosure. Ridden by Ben Harvey, the winner is trained by his father, William.Perhaps the result may have been dferent had Paul Bannon not become unseated at the final fence of his mount Butcher Barry.Best turned out in all races as usual was courtesy of Glencairn Stables.Acting stewards: Rev Colin Hall-Thompson, Max and Margaret Evine and David Aiken.Ballee jockey Toni Quail, out of action with a broken ankle as a result of a schooling accident, was helping with declarations at the meeting.A tribute was paid to the late Maurice King who for many years was a vet at the meeting.The next meeting at Tyrella is on Saturday, March . Prior to that, the North Down meeting at Kirkistown will take place on February . First race is at pm. The same evening the East Down Hunt Ball will take place at Ballydugan Mill.Victor Reid, a long time owner and breeder along with his late we Margaret, sadly passed away suddenly at hospital on Friday. His son, Neville, still has horses in training. The late Drew Reid also from Banbridge, rode many of Victorrsquos horses in point-to-points.A notable absentee at the entrance on Saturday was William McDowell, although he was present. Brian Quail did a good job in Williamrsquos absence..prettyPhoto

title: Successful launch of new lifeboat at Newcastle RNLI
story: NEWCASTLE RNLIrsquos new Mersey class leboat officially went into service this week.The Leonard Kent replaces the Eleanor and Bryant Girling all-weather leboat which had been based in the resort for almost  years and took part in numerous emergency responses during that period.When it retired from active service at Margate on Englandrsquos southeast coast in April last year, the Leonard Kent faced an uncertain future, but it is now in its new home to continue its lesaving work.The new Newcastle leboat initially spent some time at the RNLI Support Centre at Poole before being considered worthy of further service.Subsequently, it was earmarked to replace Newcastlersquos existing Mersey class leboat and will operate until building work at the harbour station has been completed and the new Shannon class all-weather leboat arrives.The Leonard Kent was moved to a boatyard at West Cowes on the Isle of Wight and treated to a le-extension programme including upgrading the electronics to the latest Systems and Information Management System.In fact, the boat would have been familiar with its surroundings, having been built in Cowes in .Newcastle RNLI leboat operations manager Lisa Ramsden said it was with a ldquosense of nostalgia that the organisation bade farewell to the Eleanor and Bryant Girling.ldquoAs we begin a new chapter, we are looking forward to being the custodians of the Leonard Kent and the volunteer crew are excited to now have an upgraded Mersey, she continued.ldquoTraining on the new upgraded Systems and Information Management System was carried out while the leboat was on passage from Dun Laoghaire to Newcastle this week.She said the removal of the original radar and navigation system helped to reduce weight and created more space in the wheelhouse.She added: ldquoAn additional benefit for us in Newcastle RNLI is that the new system will ensure the volunteer crew are prepared and proficient in the radar and navigation systems that will come with our future Shannon class leboat..prettyPhoto

title: calls to tackle unacceptable rural road litter
story: Ruth Dudley Edwards: It’s official – I am now a unionist!   Met Office Weather Warning for ice with possibility of snow or sleetNewsLatestTraffic and TravelCrimeWeatherPoliticsBusinessEducationHealthOpinionPeopleRead ThisSportFootballMotorcyclingRugby UnionOther SportOpinionWhats OnThings To DoArts and EntertainmentNightleRetroLestyleEating OutCarsHomes and GardensHomes and GardensCoronaviruse-PaperFarmingRecommendedEntertainmentTechnologyLestyleHome and GardenFashion and BeautyDealsPuzzlesPublic NoticesFree Happy AdsNewsEnvironmentCalls to tackle unacceptable rural road litterResults from an environmental charity report have shown that nearly half of rural roads surveyed across the country carry an amount of litter that exceeds the acceptable standard.By Graeme CousinsThursday, rd February , : pm  "       "  Takeaway packaging was the most common form of litter from Keep Northern Ireland Beautul’s Cleaner Neighbourhoods Report which surveyed  rural roads during the summer. It representing % of the total litter.After publishing the results of the survey Keep Northern Ireland Beautul’s community-based campaign, Live Here Love Here, and DAERA are calling on people to consider the impact of, and refrain from littering in rural areas.Dr Ian Humphreys, Chief Executive of Keep Northern Ireland Beautul, said: “Our most recent Cleaner Neighbourhoods Report has shown that rural areas are disproportionately affected by litter when compared to residential, recreational and primary retail areas.   " fill"#ea"   to our daily newsletterThe i newsletter cut through the noiseThanks for signing up!Sorry, there seem to be some issues. Please try again later.Submitting...This site is protected by reCAPTCHA and the Google Privacy Policy and Terms of Service apply.Keep Northern Ireland Beautul CEO Dr Ian Humphreys with litter-loathing puppet Al“Rural litter is particularly hazardous, seriously impacting upon our environment and economy. Tourism currently represents a considerable percentage of Northern Ireland’s GDP, but unsightly rural roads and hedgerows are unlikely to inspire atrip and can damage the perception of our region.”David Brown, Deputy President of Ulster Farmers’ Union said illegal dumping is an increasing issue in rural areas: “Fly-tipping is a scourge on the countryside and one that too many of our farmers have experienced first-hand. Dumping unwanted waste in rural areas is dangerous to human health and harmful to livestock and wildle. In the past, there have been issues where fly-tipping waste polluted watercourses and contaminated land.“When unwanted content is dumped on a farmer’s land, it becomes the responsibility of the landowner to dispose of, while local councils are left to take ownership of waste on public land and highways. This is both costly and time consuming for farmers and ratepayers.“Since the pandemic began, the amount of litter being dumped on farmers’ land has increased, with many rediscovering the outdoors for recreation. I urge all countryside visitors to be more considerate of those living locally, and of animals and to commit to taking their waste home with them.”——— ———A message from the Editor:Thank you for reading this story on our website. While I have your attention, I also have an important request to make of you.With the coronavirus lockdown having a major impact on many of our advertisers — and consequently the revenue we receive — we are more reliant than ever on you taking out a digital subscription.Subscribe to newsletter and enjoy unlimited access to the best Northern Ireland and UK news and information online and on our app. With a digital subscription, you canthan  articles, see fewer ads, enjoy faster load times, and get access to exclusive newsletters and content. Visit https:www.newsletter subscriptions now to sign up.Our journalism costs money and we rely on advertising, print and digital revenues to help to support them. By supporting us, we are able to support you in providing trusted, fact-checked content for this website.Ben LowryEditor

title: mlas vote for renewable energy goal of  by
story: Sammy Wilson wades in to row over South Down candidate selection   Veterans demand apology from Colum Eastwood over Bloody Sunday claimsNewsLatestTraffic and TravelCrimeWeatherPoliticsBusinessEducationHealthOpinionPeopleRead ThisSportFootballMotorcyclingRugby UnionOther SportOpinionWhats OnThings To DoArts and EntertainmentNightleRetroLestyleEating OutCarsHomes and GardensHomes and GardensCoronaviruse-PaperFarmingRecommendedEntertainmentTechnologyLestyleHome and GardenFashion and BeautyDealsPuzzlesPublic NoticesFree Happy AdsNewsEnvironmentMLAs vote for renewable energy goal of % by Assembly members have voted for a more ambitious -year renewable energy target for Northern Ireland.By The NewsroomThursday, rd February , : am  "       "  The amendment to draft climate change legislation for the Province sets a target of % of electricity consumption sourced from renewable sources by .The Alliance Party amendment, which was passed by  votes to , came on the second day of Assembly debate on Agriculture Minister Edwin Poots’ draft Bill.The Department for the Economy target in its recently published energy strategy is % electricity consumption from renewable sources by .   " fill"#ea"   to our daily newsletterThe i newsletter cut through the noiseThanks for signing up!Sorry, there seem to be some issues. Please try again later.Submitting...This site is protected by reCAPTCHA and the Google Privacy Policy and Terms of Service apply.A Climate Coalition NI protest took place outside Parliament Buildings at Stormont yesterday ahead of a vote on setting a target for net zero emissions. Photo: Jonathan Porter PresseyeAnother amendment, requiring the Department for the Economy to publish sector specic energy consumption plans, also passed, by  votes to .Ahead of yesterday’s resumed consideration stage, when a series of amendments were debated, Mr Poots suggested he will push for the agriculture sector to be exempt from a new net-zero carbon target.Mr Poots hit out at “stupidity” after a majority of MLAs voted for an amendment to his bill on Tuesday night that set a target of net-zero emissions by .An amendment by the Green Party Northern Ireland was passed by  votes to  on Tuesday, increasing Mr Poots’ proposed  reduction target from % to %.Party leader Clare Bailey said the move means Northern Ireland will “no longer be the only region in these islands without a net-zero emissions target”.The bill must also pass through two further Assembly stages before it goes for Royal Assent.Ms Bailey has also proposed an alternative climate change bill, which is also progressing through Stormont in the final weeks before the Assembly is dissolved for fresh elections.Northern Ireland is currently the only part of the UK which does not have its own climate legislation however UK-wide targets do apply to the Province.Mr Poots’ bill, backed by the agri-food industry, has been criticised by environmentalists as not going far enough.Meanwhile, Ms Bailey’s Bill goes further, proposing a  target for reaching net-zero carbon emissions.Mr Poots said he will be looking over the coming days at what further amendments he can table to “limit the harm and damage that will be done to many small farm families in particular across Northern Ireland as a consequence of Assembly Members defying the scientic evidence”.He claimed MLAs have been warned that voting for the net zero  target will result in , families losing their ability to farm and “huge” consequences for , people employed in the sector.“This is going to have a devastating impact on the rural community and this is very much the city folks and Sinn Fein and SDLP ganging up on rural communities, and it is an appalling situation where our Assembly took a decision which is not evidence-based, which is not science-based and is not in line with either the UK’s Climate Change Committee’s recommendations or indeed the IPCC,” he told the BBC.Mr Poots said he intends to press for an exemption for the agriculture sector from the target in the bill as well as a number of other amendments during the final stages.Ms Bailey said she is delighted that the net zero by  target was passed by MLAs but said there are a lot of other issues to look at as well.She said her focus at this time is on securing amendments to Mr Poots’ bill, rather than her own bill, which is yet to have its consideration stage.Edwin PootsClare BaileyNorthern IrelandMLAsBBC  "       "  Get the latest news on the CoronavirusWe have launched a daily public interest bulletin to deliver all the updates title: on bread and butter issues ni sorely lacks people to see the job through
story: New Presbyterian Moderator: My father walked out when I was three - it has taught me empathy   Met Office Weather Warning for ice with possibility of snow or sleetNewsLatestTraffic and TravelCrimeWeatherPoliticsBusinessEducationHealthOpinionPeopleRead ThisSportFootballMotorcyclingRugby UnionOther SportOpinionWhats OnThings To DoArts and EntertainmentNightleRetroLestyleEating OutCarsHomes and GardensHomes and GardensCoronaviruse-PaperFarmingRecommendedEntertainmentTechnologyLestyleHome and GardenFashion and BeautyDealsPuzzlesPublic NoticesFree Happy AdsNewsOpinionOn bread and butter issues NI sorely lacks people to see the job throughA letter from Tom Ekin:By LettersFriday, th February , : am  "       "  Letter to the editorAgain I heard an academic say just the other day that we have had many health reviews and the same old problems persist – hence the hospital problems exemplied by Daisy Hill. This is true of so much in Northern Ireland. Look at the failures which cost the taxpayer and the exchequer millions, as well as lives which we don’t seem to count.Just a few of our failures:   " fill"#ea"   to our daily newsletterThe i newsletter cut through the noiseThanks for signing up!Sorry, there seem to be some issues. Please try again later.Submitting...This site is protected by reCAPTCHA and the Google Privacy Policy and Terms of Service apply.The NHS not rationalised to give a better serviceThe York Street interchange not started The ‘Streets Ahead’ improvement scheme for Belfast’s Great Victoria StreetRubbish being shipped to other countries across the worldSchool underperformanceThe removal of peace walls ... And so on. No doubt there are many more.The common features are the lack of drive, the lack of a plan to complete, the lack of ideas about persuading the people who object to the changes to accept that they’re beneficial, and the lack of will on the part of politicians to make the hard choices.Too many of our bright, dynamic achievers are too busy running successful organisations to spend time and energy tackling the big non-political or sectarian issues.It is hard to see that there will be any change, no matter what the politicians promise, unless there is someone appointed with authority to make the changes with courage, ability, and drive.Tom Ekin, businessman and former Alliance councillor in BelfastA message from the Editor:Thank you for reading this story on our website.
